body: When will the resources be uploaded in IITBombayX? How will I get the information?

The resources will be released on Thursday of each week. This information will be updated in the [Course Info page][1]. The [course schedule][2] shows the full course related resource release and assignment submission due dates information.


  [1]: https://www.iitbombayx.in/courses/IITBombayX/ET601Tx/2015-16/info
  [2]: https://www.iitbombayx.in/courses/IITBombayX/ET601Tx/2015-16/0a02e713ddd846ff9c41ba49bf50d133/

Thank You for pointing this out. The correction has been made. The module will be available now from Jan 7 12:00 noon IST (06:30 UTC).
I wish to know the procedure for getting ISTE certificate. Thereis no info on the the tab "For ISTE Certificate".

The tab has not been populated as the release is scheduled tomorrow and we are finalizing the formal procedure and verification methods. 

ISTE certificate will be provided to participants (Engineering College Instructors from India) who perform additional activities (apart from graded activities in the course) that will be uploaded in this section.

Participants who are interested in getting an ISTE certificate should:
a) Indicate this preference in Course Entry Survey (which will be uploaded in Getting Started section on Jan 7)
b) Provide proofs for their identity and role in college. (Mechanism will be explained in the survey)
c) Do regular MOOC graded activities i.e. Knowledge Quizzes, Reflection Quizzes and Resource Creation Assignments
d) Do ISTE certificate related assignments.

Once they satisfy both MOOC requirements and ISTE certificate requirements, the certificates will be mailed to the institution address.
I'm from a Management Institution, **not**  from an Engineering College. Can I apply for an ISTE Certificate?
Sorry.\n\nThe ISTE certificate arrangement is only valid for Engineering College instructors.
Thank you

I'm from a Polytechnic college. Can I apply for an ISTE Certificate?
Sorry. At this moment certificates are issued only for Engineering college instructors.
How do I get Certificate?\n

ISTE certificate will be provided to participants (Engineering College Instructors from India) who perform additional activities (apart from graded activities in the course) that will be uploaded in this section.

Participants who are interested in getting an ISTE certificate should: 

 - Indicate this preference in Course Entry Survey (which will be
   uploaded in Getting Started section on Jan 7)  
 - Provide proofs for their identity and role in college. (Mechanism
   will be explained in the survey)
 - Do regular MOOC graded activities i.e. Knowledge Quizzes, Reflection
   Quizzes and Resource Creation Assignments 
 - Do ISTE certificate related assignments.

Once they satisfy both MOOC requirements and ISTE certificate requirements, the certificates will be mailed to the institution address.

Knowledge Quiz : Q2 

Why this is not a learning objective:
At the end of classes on Trigonometry(Triangles), students will be able to Construct triangles of stated dimensions using only ruler and compass.

Given below are learning objectives designed by a High School Mathematics teacher for the topic Triangles. Which of the following is a valid learning objective?
At the end of the classes given drawings of 5 triangles, students will be able to classify them as equilateral, isosceles or scalene., At the end of classes on Trigonometry, students will be able to Construct triangles of stated dimensions using only ruler and compass., - correct
At the end of the classes on Triangles, students will be able to understand equilateral triangles.
At the end of the classes given drawings of 5 triangles, students will be able to classify them as equilateral, isosceles or scalene.
At the end of classes on Trigonometry(Triangles), students will be able to Construct triangles of stated dimensions using only ruler and compass.
At the end of classes on Triangles, students will be able to learn about real life applications of triangle properties with interest.

hello all, We at our institute using Outcome Based Teaching Learning from last three years and have seen tremendous effect on active participation of students in learning process. 
You can arrange a small play or involve them in process for example:

To show modes of heat transfer...
1. give your chalk/pen/duster to first bench student and ask him to give it to last bench student without leaving his position. He will pass it to another student and chain will be formed. This defines Conduction.
2. for convection, ask the last bench student to bring that back to you by himself. This shows movement of matter for heat transfer that is convection.
3. For radiation, now just throw whatever you have (Take care..!). Neither you have moved nor the receiver. And no medium is used.

Learning objectives for every concept big and small, should cover Validity, Measurability and Specificity.\nIf these factors are not present in the learning objectives, it can lead to ambiguity, and miscommunication. As you know that learning objectives are ways to bring students and teacher's expectations on the same page. Clearly defining learning objectives ensures that student is very clear about - what to expect, whom to expect from, how to measure or evaluate the outcome and what duration is necessary for the given topic.

I had been teaching control theory and i found a couple of times that the students are not understanding the underlying concepts of Mathematical Modeling. This happened after i asked a question to relate the procedure and its application to physical world. A lot of unexpected (were very much expected after i started understanding this course) answers came up like Mathematical modelling is done to do inter-conversion between various mechanical systems to electrical circuits. So i determined the learning objective to relate the purpose of modeling,by explaining them how it determines the relation between input and output. I also explained them to relate the process of modeling to any system whose behaviour is not known

Learning objectives:
1) Applying conservation of energy principle
2) Understanding relationship between inputs and outputs
3) The purpose of modeling
4) Relate any physical system with mathematical modeling

Interesting points being discussed.

Let me put my views as a teacher/instructor first. Quizzes can also be made creative, challenging and motivating. Though this is going to be discussed in coming weeks, do look for Eric Mazur and Peer Instruction in the internet.

Now from a learners perspective the assignments or activities are more useful for me if there is "pertinency" associated with it. i.e. there should be a relevance for the assignment in their immediate practice. 

Lets take 2 examples and see whether this is making sense. I would really like to hear your views about this.

Example 1 - For the topic on Eucledian distance that was discussed in the videos, will an assignment like "Given physical map of the locality, convert it into cartesian coordinates and identify the shortest distance from your house to school. Use the location of the school as zero reference point (0,0)"

As a learner the exercise of converting a map to cartesian coordinate system and then trying to find out shortest path is interesting and also relevant. Since there is personalization (distance from my house to school) the "Xeroxing" effect is not useful. And again I will know various ways in which I can go to school, and also know the shortest way in which I can reach it (On days when I do not want to reach school fast, I know various other ways to take !!!). 

Example 2 - Consider this course's peer assessment activity where you have to write a learning objective and grade 2 others based on the criteria of validity, specificity and measurability.
Question to others - Is it making the activity relevant? Or is it again falling into the same trap?

This is my humble opinion

**Teacher -> student** = asking questions after completing each topic (to ensure that students have understood), starting a topic with a question (which is interesting) answer to which they would obtain in the class.{for example if I am going to teach heights and distances in school, first (i.e before teaching the method) I would give students some real life problem, like finding the height of a tower if the cable attached to the top has known length and if the cable is attached to gnd at a particular dist from the foot of the tower. Now this problem is simple and some students may tell that we could use Pythagoras theorem and find the height of the tower. Now I pose my second question, i.e what will you do if the length of the cable is unknown and only the angle that it makes with the gnd is known, at this point students will ponder about the solution. Now they are interested. Introduce the method to them NOW . They will be receptive and will be in a position to appreciate the method. Again after class give them a question that you have not taught and is a bit higher in standard, ask them to ponder over the solution. In the next class analyse their solutions (at least the approach that they took towards the problem ) and tell them the correct method.

**Student ->Teacher** = read the topics for the days class beforehand and make a rough idea, when the teacher entertains questions ask him/her.
good objectives

You can always assess the "understand" objectively by asking pointed questions. For example when you teach probability, it has to be understood that it must lie between 0 and 1. One can then devise questions which will lead to correct answer only if this point is understood.

This is not always true. The create level can also mean creating a design using the concepts learnt in class, The question can also be a pen and paper question, but it qualifies as a CREATE level question
Can we then safely say that asking a question that is out of syllabus, so to say, qualifies for the create level?\n

Learning objectives are very important in these days. In olden days (ie. in my days of studying), syllabus and references will be given. But sometimes we do not understand why we are learning this in this topic. Thanks to blooms taxonomy. However, it is question that whether the learning objective given is clear. I have seen many institute following the instruction of giving learning objectives simply by repeating the phrases. For eg. X able to make student understand Y and so on. It should be given clearly, consciously and more importantly must reflect the actual syllabus as well practice/applications.
I don't get you ThivaharanS. Learning objectives should be framed before the course instruction begins.
Do remember it's India, where one have no control on any thing like bla-bla .... Pl. do not wait for the last date - it is the date "**TILL**" one can submit.
How will you measure whether your first and second learning objectives have been met by the student?
You need to refine the learning objectives more. Check them against the rubrics for measurability and validity.

How can we fix a "Learning Objective" just based on the "Ability of the students"? (or) It should be in a sense "More General". For example, for a common course "Engineering Mechanics", Learning Objective is common for both IITians and Tier - 2 Engineering Colleges. Syllabus and Given Common Learning Objective are more clear to IITians than Tier - 2 Engineering colleges. As mentioned in the example, estimation of distance between two points has three objectives. These three objectives are also applicable for below - average students. Aren't they? I also personally feel that the clarity of "Learning Objectives" has a certain link with "Ability of the student". X able to make a student understand Y but same X is not able to make another Student understand same Y. How this can be tackled?

The initial discussion with students of my class (B.Tech III year) was on cognitive levels and importance of each level in revised Bloom's Taxonomy. This helped students to understand the way a topic or an entire subject must be learned.Then I discussed the learning objectives of Web Technologies subject. The students were very happy as the direction in which they have to see and learn Web Technologies subject is known prior to them. They were even excited as the outcomes of the subject are clearly explained. Thanks to Prof. Sahana Murthy for explaining the methodology to be applied or used while preparing learning objectives.

- We need to distinguish properly between cognitive levels and action verbs.\n \n - An action verb can appear in various cognitive levels, so the meaning that we want to convey should also be considered while preparing learning objectives.

Learning objectives can be prepared for any subject. They are not related to I or II year of study. These objectives can even be prepared for a specific topic in a subject.\n\nAccording to me these learning objectives will help in reducing the mismatch between teachers expectations and students learning. They are stepping stones for moving towards OBE system of education.

Learning objectives are clear and concise statements that describe the intended outcomes of instruction.
Learning outcomes represent the skills that learners can expect to demonstrate after completing the
instruction. Outcome statements must be specific, observable, and measurable.

ISTE certificate will be provided to participants (Engineering College Instructors from India) who perform additional activities (apart from graded activities in the course) that will be uploaded in this section.
Participants who are interested in getting an ISTE certificate should:

 - Indicate this preference in Course Entry Survey
 - Provide proofs for their identity and role in college.
 - Do regular MOOC graded activities i.e. Knowledge Quizzes,

Hi all, I feel, the word "understand" is very much appropriate to structure a learning objective. The basics of "application" and "analysis" depend on the criticality of understanding. "Memorizing/recall" may require the least extent of understanding. "Application (without analysis)" requires some higher level of understanding, at least from one point of view of the worked out examples. "Analysis followed by application" requires the highest level of understanding, from different points of view, which enables one to define the problem, accordingly choose the proper formula as well as successful application of the formula to solve the problem.
MEASURABLE MEANS - ASSESSMENT CUM OUTCOME BASED TEACHING LEARNING OBJECTIVES.

FOLLOWING POINTS SHOULD BE KEPT IN OUR MIND WHILE DEVISING LEARNING OBJECTIVES.

- What do you want the student to be able to do?
- What knowledge, skill or abilities should the ideal student participant demonstrate?
- How will students be able to demonstrate what they learned?
- How does this program and outcome fit within the Division's Student Learning Outcomes?

Writing summary at the end of the class is good but it cannot be a substitute to writing learning objectives. By not providing LO at the beginning of the class, you are not setting the focus. At the end of the class when you give your checklist, the students may be dismayed to find that they have not really understood the topics with that point of view which you are emphasizing at the end of the class. Therefore LO at the beginning of course, beginning of each class etc is extremely important.

Designing Learning Objectives:
In designing learning objectives, it is important to include:
1. a specific and observable behavior (use a measurable verb - for example, "the student will be able to diagnose X...");
2. the important condition under which the performance is to occur (e.g.: in a clinical setting...), and what tools or assistance will be provided (using a stethoscope...); and
3. the standard - what will constitute acceptable performance (e.g.: 98% of the time...).
Avoid vague and hard to measure phrasing like: understand, know or learn about, and try to use more specific language such as: identify, construct, compare and contrast, interpret, diagram, translate, predict,analyze.

Dear All,

Update on 14 Jan 2016,

**We regret to inform you that, due to policy and logistics issues, we are unable to provide ISTE certificates for ET601Tx.**  

Hence there are no additional assignments and you need not upload any additional documents. We hope that this will not stop you from continuing with this course.

You can still get the IITBombayX Honour Code certificate if you do the graded activities and score an aggregate of 50% or more.

Over the past few days we are seeing lot of discussion forum posts and emails regarding certificate. So this post has been created to answer all of them. Please follow this post to see updates.

##Eligibility##

----------

Only Engineering College Instructors are eligible for ISTE certification.

##Regarding the Survey##


----------


 - I have filled the survey, but when I come back to the page it shows
   blank. Does this mean my response has not been recorded? How can I
   understand whether my response has been recorded?

*Ans*: No, if you have filled the survey once, at the end you will receive the following response message:  **Your response has been recorded. Now please proceed with the course.**  If you get this it means that survey is complete.

##Regarding process for registering for certificate##


----------

 - The survey says that I will receive an email from outreach team. When
   will I get it?

*Ans*: Certificate generation is a separate process and it will take some time for the outreach team to process all the data. So it will take 1-2 working days (we are trying to minimize it as far as possible). So please be patient, the mail will reach you this week itself.
 

 - Is there a format for approval letter from Head of Institution? Can
   you upload a template?

*Ans*: At this moment we do not have a template for the same. However the following points should be taken care while creating the approval letter:

 3. The letter should be in the institute letter head and should have the sign and seal of the head of institution.

 4. The letter should specify your full name and your department and should certify you as a bonafide faculty of the institution.

 5. The letter should specify that the head of institution is aware that you are taking this course for obtaining 2-week equivalent ISTE certificate and has his approval for the same.

Updates will be posted in this post itself.

Course Objectives are broader and will subsume a lot of lesson/topic level learning objectives. It can also be created by linking more than one topic within the course.

For e.g. consider the case of Mathematics for a high school student which has Coordinate Geometry and Algebra as topics/lessons within it.
A broad course objective for this could be that, *At the end of course student will be able to create optimized travel design plans such as design bus pickup routes for the school to optimize travel expenditure.* 
If you carefully look at this objective, the students have to make use of the distance formulae they learnt in the coordinate geometry to identify least distances, identify the optimum number of buses required by comparing distance travelled in various paths,  evaluate the economic path by creating simple linear equations based on mileage of the bus and finally combine all these to generate the design for bus pickup routes.

Learning objectives at topic level can now be thought of as sub-components within this broad objective. Important thing to note is that these learning objectives can also be at create levels like *Design of walking-efficient city* example discussed in the LeD Video.
Abbreviate without loosing essential content. For e.g. Engineering can be Engg., Technology can be Tech. etc.

Following are the learning objectives on this topic:

(i) Students will be able to calculate absolute maximum, absolute minimum of the given functions without drawing the graph.

2) Doing LbD activities
3) Participating in discussions
4) Doing the Knowledge Quizzes

Learning Objectives:
1) Calculate various circuit parameters of a MOSFET

3) An ability to design Transistor-Level CMOS Logic circuit for a given functionality
4) An ability to estimate and compute the power consumption of a VLSI circuit.

7) Learn to Analyze Gate Function and Timing Characteristics of a multi input CMOS Logic gates

9) To understand and apply various techniques to reduce delay of gate
10) An ability to design static CMOS and dynamic clocked CMOS circuits.
11) Draw layout of a CMOS circuit
12) An ability to understand and explain the role of parasitic elements in a CMOS digital
13) Understand various logic design styles and compare them with static CMOS logic design
14) Understanding and analyze working of SRAM cell and DRAM cell

Course outcome is the benefits realised by the learning.  
Objectives and outcomes are not the same.

Course outcome: After completing the course, students will design and fabricate a machine using fluid power circuit.

Today, I started teaching Distributed Systems in this semester.
My topic was introduction.
I shared the following learning objectives with the students:

**Recall level objective** - Define a distributed system

**Understand level objective** - Explain the consequences of this definition

**Apply level objective** – Calculate the price/performance ratio for a mainframe and a distributed system

**Analyze level objective** – Infer whether a centralized system is better than a distributed system from a price/performance ratio perspective

**Evaluate level objective** – Contrast a distributed system with a computer network (or independent PC)

**Create level objective** – Extend the components of an operating system to a distributed operating system, such as file system becomes distributed file system, and so on. 

We covered most of them in the lecture, except for Evaluate and Create Level.

Well, optimally it should be a combination of both of them. A syllabus is made taking into the fact that all the topics are important and hence the students should be taught all the topics in the syllabus. However, simply teaching the syllabus without telling them how and in what form its going to b related to our daily life is useless and meaningless. Hence it should be a combination of both. However most often than not its not possible. Hence I suggest to minimise the time allotted to topics that are less going to influence (important) and stress more on basics so that they an pursue the other topics at higher classes if they are interested in these topics.

Understand is more generic. Its clear from this discussion itself that some agrees that "Understand" is measurable while others disagrees. So better to avoid such confusions in the learning objectives. Also, when we say "Understand" what is the level up to which you expect the student to understand. It has multiple levels right. Eg. By saying he should be able to understand, do we mean just summarize the topic, or solve problems on the topic, or explain the different types, categories, application of the topic, or design a similar system etc. So as far as learning objective is concerned it must be specific and measurable. So better to avoid "Understand" unless you add more details into it like "Understand so and so topic so that he will be able to design so and so system given the following parameters.\n

Sometimes all the los may not suit to all students. it may be required to differentiate the students according to their level of interest, understanding and motivate them to achieve their objective at lower level first and moving toward higher level.

It is generally observed that IQ level and interest of different students in different subjects or in different topics of the same subject could be different. In that case some students may be able to achieve lower level of objectives such as to recall etc. while some may be able to achieve the evaluation or create level. Accordingly students should be helped to achieve lower level objectives first and be motivated to move towards higher level. Especially for Engineering degree students these are my observations.

There may be scenarios where formula is not recalled by students correctly. So in this case, ask them to write whatever little they remember. Then in the pair phase, you should ask students to first compare the answers and then ask them to solve the question together. 

This will allow students to discuss how the formula is being applied in the new situation and also learn from each other. The discussion is the key to the learning and your Share Phase question is a good follow-up where the students can verify their understanding.

I understand that the terminology is debatable and there are strong views on both sides. This is the exact reason why we didn't differentiate the objectives and outcomes. The definition of Learning Objective states that they are measurable performance outcomes of the learner. So how are they different from outcomes?

However, a bigger question to ask at this point is what difference does it make whether you write them as Learning Outcome or Learning Objective? 

At the end of the lesson/topic you want them to be able to "perform" some "thing" related to the topic that is going to be useful for them. And by specifying it in advance you are letting both students and yourself know what each of you should target to achieve.

My Class experiences: A benefit of the think-pair-share is that the teacher has an opportunity to hear from many students — including the "quiet" ones. Good to hear that the students enjoyed. However 1 feedback we would give you at this point is:
 
1) Keep Think Phase simple and doable by all (may be an important part of algorithm)

2) Keep shorter durations for both Think (1-3 min) and Pair (5-8 min). The reason is that there are chances that many students may already complete activity earlier and they will get restless.

The idea to compare student's answer with instructors is good. However if you want to connect multiple topics, it would be a good idea to keep it a little longer. Because it is the share phase where your role as an instructor becomes critical to summarize and highlight important points.
The impact of TPS can be shared in the discussion forum
Designing TPS for Subject like Injection moulding is difficult. \nTPS can be designed for Analytical subjects where multiple paths are there for a problem.

Did the students enjoy the activity? 

Here are some feedbacks that I would give you
 
1) Keep Think Phase simple and doable by all (may be an important part of algorithm in pseudo code form). Will all the students know the rule? If not show the formula in the board/PPT

2) If you are attempting pair programming, then provide some initial block of code from where students can start and then take it forward. Also the discussion aspect of the algorithm or pseudo code is missing. In Pair phase the discussion is the key aspect as they will extend the Think Phase output by comparing each other's algorithms. 

3) Keep shorter durations for both Think (1-3 min) and Pair (5-8 min). The reason is that there are chances that many students may already complete activity earlier and they will get restless.

4) While sharing differences between student's code and instructor's solution, make sure you highlight the key concepts involved. If you want to connect multiple topics, it would be a good idea to keep it a little longer. Because it is the Share Phase where your role as an instructor becomes critical to summarize and highlight important points.

Incompressible flow equation[edit]
In most flows of liquids, and of gases at low Mach number, the density of a fluid parcel can be considered to be constant, regardless of pressure variations in the flow. Therefore, the fluid can be considered to be incompressible and these flows are called incompressible flow. Bernoulli performed his experiments on liquids, so his equation in its original form is valid only for incompressible flow. A common form of Bernoulli's equation, valid at any arbitrary point along a streamline, is:

{v^2 \over 2}+gz+{p\overho}=	ext{constant}
 
 
 
 
(A)
where:

v\, is the fluid flow speed at a point on a streamline,
g\, is the acceleration due to gravity,
z\, is the elevation of the point above a reference plane, with the positive z-direction pointing upward – so in the direction opposite to the gravitational acceleration,
p\, is the pressure at the chosen point, and
ho\, is the density of the fluid at all points in the fluid.
For conservative force fields, Bernoulli's equation can be generalized as:[9]

{v^2 \over 2}+\Psi+{p\overho}=	ext{constant}
where ? is the force potential at the point considered on the streamline. E.g. for the Earth's gravity ? = gz.

The following two assumptions must be met for this Bernoulli equation to apply:[9]

the flow must be incompressible – even though pressure varies, the density must remain constant along a streamline;
friction by viscous forces has to be negligible.
By multiplying with the fluid density ho, equation (A) can be rewritten as:


	frac12\, ho\, v^2\, +\, ho\, g\, z\, +\, p\, =\, 	ext{constant}\,
or:


q\, +\, ho\, g\, h\,
  =\, p_0\, +\, ho\, g\, z\,
  =\, 	ext{constant}\,
where:

q\, =\, 	frac12\, ho\, v^2 is dynamic pressure,
h\, =\, z\, +\,  rac{p}{ho g} is the piezometric head or hydraulic head (the sum of the elevation z and the pressure head)[10][11] and
p_0\, =\, p\, +\, q\, is the total pressure (the sum of the static pressure p and dynamic pressure q).[12]
The constant in the Bernoulli equation can be normalised. A common approach is in terms of total head or energy head H:

H\, =\, z\, +\,  rac{p}{ho g}\, +\,  rac{v^2}{2\,g}\, =\, h\, +\,  rac{v^2}{2\,g},
The above equations suggest there is a flow speed at which pressure is zero, and at even higher speeds the pressure is negative. Most often, gases and liquids are not capable of negative absolute pressure, or even zero pressure, so clearly Bernoulli's equation ceases to be valid before zero pressure is reached. In liquids – when the pressure becomes too low – cavitation occurs. The above equations use a linear relationship between flow speed squared and pressure. At higher flow speeds in gases, or for sound waves in liquid, the changes in mass density become significant so that the assumption of constant density is invalid.

To introduce students to
1) Synthesis and processing methods for glasses and glass ceramics.

3) Electrical, mechanical and optical properties of glasses and glass ceramics
4) Various applications of glasses and glass ceramics

Think of it as Math project where students have to create a toy model. But the create level objective is not coming because it is an actual creation activity. Rather students have to: 

 - first think of places within city where pedestrians can walk
   (Recall),
 - comprehend that for making walking efficient they should get minimum
   distances (Understand),

 - apply distance formula to calculate least distances between various
   spots in city (Apply),

 - Analyze possible set of walking paths that pedestrians can take
   across the city (Analyze),

 - Judge which distance/path to choose in case two points can be joined by more than one line

 - Finally design the overall path after taking all the decisions.

The following TPS activity was given to the students studying Building Enterprise Applications course.
Think: Think individually about the appropriate tools (programming languages, databases etc.) to be selected for developing an Hospital Management application.  Think about any five modules of your choice.
Pair: Discuss your tools with your neighbors and get an understanding of why the selected tools are appropriate.
Share: Share and compare your tools with the tools suggested by the Instructor.  Get a clear picture of appropriateness of various tools in developing the application.

The above activity kept the students engaged and they came out with the appropriate Programming languages / databases needed to develop the application.  After this activity, everybody was clear about why a particular programming language or database is suitable for various modules.  This also helped in identifying all the necessary modules in developing Hospital Management system.

The following TPS activity was given to the students studying Microprocessor Peripheral and Application course.

Course Topic: Interrupt Structure of Microprocessor 8085.

LO: Students will be able to judge to decide among different interrupts of  Microprocessor 8085   for critical situations.

TPS :

Think Phase [2 mins] : Identify what are the different Interrupts in Microprocessor 8085.

Pair Phase [5mins]: Discuss the function of various interrupts of interrupt structure of 8085 microprocessor.

Share Phase [10 mins] : Now share and compare your discussion with the explanation of instructor on various interrupts of 8085 microprocessor. Identify different discussion point and share them with the class.

________________________________________

Students Response to TPS Activity:

All most all of the student in Think phase able to identify interrupts in 8085 microprocessor.Then they were paired in Pair Phase for 5 Min, activity kept the students engaged and they came out with the appropriate decision to decide among different interrupts for Critical situation .finally after discussion as instructor I have shared my view related to different interrupt related to 8085 and how to select appropriate interrupts for critical situation. One think I noticed that it was fun for students because some of were explain their decision on critical situation interrupts how to choose  and also some were able to see their own mistakes. And finally student shared their answer with class. Its really fun for them, they put their effort as well as its first time they shared their view in front of class what they thought about it.

It appears that you wrote topics at random, not following the traditional order in which C-Programming syllabus is structured.In one interaction, that many topics cannot be covered. If we consider them as different topics namely 
1. flowcharts, algorithms  
2. data types
3. Functions

for the first one the objectives could be

The student will be able to
(i) define the characteristics of algorithm and flowchart
(ii) identify the role of pseudo code in problem solving
(iii) illustrate the workflow or information flow to solve a given problem using algorithm and its flow chart.

TPS Creation Activity - CS Domain

1) Topic: CPU scheduling Algorithms and the Students (Software Engineering Major)

2) Learning Objectives:

2.1) The students shall be able to categories various CPU scheduling algorithm on their  
commonality, differences and judge most appropriate algorithm for a given criterion 
to allocate CPU burst.

2.2) The student shall be able to formulate appropriate scheduling algorithm for solving a 
real-life problem such as "Barber Queuing Problem".

3) TPS - Active Teaching-Learning Strategy

3.1) Think: Select suitable algorithm from i.e. First-Come-First-Serve (FCFS) and Shortest Job First (SJF) algorithm individually for a given criterion. (3 Min)

3.2) Pair : Compare the suitable algorithm on the outcome of think phase for a given criterion with your partner by convincing or getting convinced. (5 Min)

3.3) Share: Share pair phase outcome with other pairs in class and formulate an appropriate CPU scheduling algorithm. As a teacher, I extended students learning by suggesting the solution for solving a real-life problem such as "Barber Queuing Problem" and depicted the role of active learning facilitator. (10 Min)

Once I asked a question in an Internal Test, 
"What do you understand by the term 'Fluid Power'?" 
and in response to this question all students wrote different answers only few students wrote the answer whatever has been explained in the class. 
One student who wrote different than discussed in class argued that he should be given full marks for his answer whatever he has written. 
He was emphasizing on the question itself and said that as the question is containing the phrase "What do you understand" means student has to write whatever is known to or understood by him/her and for such question there is not any specific answer. So he claimed for full marks for that question. 
Finally i agreed to students argument and gave the max marks for that particular question to all those students who had at least attempted that question.

So what i mean to say that the word 'Understand' is really problematic and hence we should avoid it while defining our LO/CO.

*TOPIC-Vapour compression refrigeration system*

In a practical class of 20 students, the students were explained the schematic of a simple vapour compression refrigeration system. Then, they were asked to draw the schematic as well as the T-S and P-H diagrams based on the earlier concepts of thermal science (thermodynamics). students were given the time of 20 minutes for the individual activity. and thereafter they were told to discuss there diagrams with the neighbours. For this another 10 minutes were given. Later on a discussion was done among the students in the share part of the activity and students were made to discuss their results. At the end, 5 questions were asked from the students.

**IMPACT of activity** The students were very enthusiastic, engaged throughout the activity and felt completely satisfied by their performance. The students answered all the questions correctly.

Suppose I frame a LO that at the end of this topic student will be able to list....

and in assessment of this LO if I ask a question that, List.....

Here being a teacher as I know that I had listed about 10 points while teaching which are the most important but in response to the question none of the student has listed all those 10 points but various students listed various no of points amongst the discussed. So the question is have they all learnt all those 10 points, in this case answer is no. Because specific measurability was not defined in your LO.

Instead of this, now you can frame the LO as at the end of this topic student will be able to list all the 10 ....
and also you have to ask question like, List all the 10.....
answers with listing of all the 10 will add to assessment of your LO with specific measurability.

I hope this has cleared you the measurability of a LO.

the LOs are for a specific topic or lecture
but the COs are on broad scale.

While defining the LOs for a specific topic make sure that a group of LOs from different topics should contribute to attainment of a particular CO.

For this we need to map all the LOs from all the topics to the COs.
eg. if i have LOs for different topics such as A, B, C, D
A--1,2,3,4
B--1,2,3,4
...
..
and so on
Then for a CO i must map the LOs such as 
CO1 depends on A1, A2, B1, B2
CO2 depends on A3, A4, C1, C2

doing this i can map my all LOs to COs and then I can carry out the assessment of my COs i.e. attainment of COs

A TPS activity was performed in the class:
First the definitions of disjoint events and independent events was given in the class and for the think phase a simple true or false question was asked: (i) Null event and any event A are always disjoint. (ii) Null event and any event A are always independent.
In the pair phase a question was asked : Is independence same as disjointness?
Very interesting debate ensued in the share phase!!
A very satisfying experience for me as the teacher.

Sub-Topic: Extreme values of a function: 

Think: Recall & identify whether the given function has extreme values or no, using extreme value theorem & first derivative theorem. And then calculate the the extreme values of the function.(2 min) 

Pair: Discuss the solutions with correct justifications with the neighbouring students & help the other student to understand & grow with the concepts.(5 min) 

Share: Discuss with the entire class, the solutions obtained how & why, and create a problem of similar kind. (5 min)

The activity mentioned is only the think part and if a simple enough function is given then can be done by almost all. Then one should be able to design a pair activity like whether the local extremum is also a global one etc.

Name of the topic: Orthographic Projections

Target Audience: First Year students of Engineering

Learning objective: Draw orthographic projection representations of non-complex machine components in first angle orthographic projections.

Think phase question:
Differentiate the first and third angle methods of orthographic projection.
(5 min)

Pair phase question:
Compare each other’s points. Together, draw the freehand orthographic projections from the given pictorial view of an object using first angle method of projection.
(15-20 min)

Share phase task:
Compare your solution with instructor’s projections for the given pictorial view. Identify points (if any) where your solution is different and share them with the class.
(15-20 min)

Dear All,

This is a clarification message for answering all those queries regarding the "Designing your own TPS" activity.

 - Q1. Should I answer all the 5 questions for this activity?

*Ans*: No you need to answer only the question relevant to your domain.

 - Q2. How will I do the Peer Assessment activity?

*Ans*: Please refer to the [Peer Assessment Instructions][1] document that has been updated in the Course Info page to understand how to perform the activity.

 - Q3. The marking shows that I have 6/45, whereas problem score indicates 6/9. So which is the right one?

*Ans*: The section contains 5 questions which are of 9 mark each. Hence the total maximum mark possible from the section is 45. Since you are answering only the question (related your domain) your answer is actually evaluated out of 9 possible marks for the question. 
Please note that, the TPS activity is a mandatory activity to answer the Resource Creation assignment only. We will not directly factor in your Peer assessed grades as there is lot of subjectivity in it. The Peer Assessed grades will be primarily used for filtering the top assignments at the end of the course.  

If you have any further queries/clarifications please post them below this thread so that we can answer them. 


  [1]: http://iitbombayx.in/c4x/IITBombayX/ET601Tx/asset/ORA_Instructions.pdf

Like any change, students will take time to adjust to the new strategy. So a suggestion give some TPS icebreakers such that students get used to the idea of paired discussions. Put in a lot of guided questions and prompts if you see students not discussing. And most importantly tell them why you are asking them to do the Pair and Share.\n\nThese strategies have been found as effective mechanisms to get more student buy-in with active learning strategies.

The question of completing syllabus is a very genuine and repeated problem faced by several instructors. We do not recommend you to straight away do TPS or any other Active Learning strategy in all your lectures. But make use of these strategies when you want to achieve higher order objectives in classroom.

As is common with Higher Order learning objectives, there will be multiple concepts from different sections that you may be able to connect through activities like TPS. So if you spend some time on performing this connection correctly (while designing your activity) and make sure the students do the activity in the class itself so that you can provide immediate feedback, the results are truly remarkable. But yes, the initial effort is daunting and would require each of us to have some practice with both the content and pedagogy.  

A question that I usually ask many teachers when I receive such question is: Will you be able to provide effective learning to your students if you follow the traditional methods to complete syllabus? If the answer is yes, then such active learning strategies are not required. But if it is a no, then why not try such strategies for 1 or 2 topics and see how far students are going ahead.

We have to fix a threshold based on the Blooms Taxonomy Level. For example if it comes under understanding the threshold may be fixed as 4 (Because studetns can easily remember the concepts). For applying (or) analyzing levels the threshold may be fixed as 2.5. Then we can calculate the attainment of LO as (Number of students attained the Thresold value)/(Total number of students).

Students: First Year Engg. (Sem II)
Learning Objective:At the End of Class student should able to solve problems based on Mean Value Theorem.

**Think Phase:[3 min]**
Recall the conditions to apply Mean value theorem and identify whether the given function satisfies these condition on given domain.
**Pair Phase:[5 min]**
Discuss the value of f'(c) among neighboring students and help each other to find it and grew with the concept.
**Share Phase:[5 min]**
student share the correct answer with entire class and how it can be obtained. Develop some functions on their own to check Mean value theorem.

Think, Pair, Share – Sample Starters
Sample Starters for Individual Thinking before Pairing:
Think of three things you know about ___ . (e.g., scientific notation).
Take about 5 minutes to jot down things you remember about ___ . (e.g., triangles).
Write a definition for ___ . (e.g., rhombus).
What is the difference between ___ and ___ ? (e.g., the instructions solve and simplify)
What is the same and what is different between ___ and ___ ? (e.g. mean and median)
Think about different ways that you can ___ . (e.g. model the addition of -7 and +5)
You are going to look at a diagram on the overhead for a few moments. Then I will cover the diagram
and ask you to individually write things that you remember about the diagram.
Read the set of instructions and highlight any that you don’t understand.
Read the set of instructions and reword them so they would be easier for a Grade __ student to understand.
Think about the activities we did in class over the last few days. Summarize the mathematics concepts
that you learned and state the concepts that are still unclear to you.
Sample Think/Pair/Share Process for Problem Solving:
Step 1: Think Individually think about the following (3-5 minutes):
What information do you need to solve the problem?
What information do you already know?
What tools and strategies could you use?
What questions do you need to ask your group?
Step 2: Pair With a partner, jot down ideas to help you get started with the problem (2-3
minutes). You may use any of the tools provided in the classroom, including
calculators to help with estimating.
Step 3: Share Take turns sharing ideas in a larger group (3-4 minutes).
Step 4: Decide on the first strategy your group would like to apply to solve the problem.
Record other possible strategies. You may want to revise your plan as you work
through the problem.
Step 5: The person with ______________________________________ shares your
favoured strategy with the whole class.
…adapted from TIPS: Section 4 – TIPS for

Dear All,

We understand that the Progress Chart is having some ambiguity. This post is to clarify how Progress is going to be calculated for IITBombayX certificate.

If you had looked into the [Course Handout][1], there are three types of Graded assignments:

 1. Knowledge Quiz - (weightage 60%)
 2. Resource Creation Assignment - (weightage 30%)
 3. Reflection Quiz - (weightage 10%)

Your Total Score = 0.6*KQavg + 0.3*RCavg + 0.1*RQavg; where,

KQavg = (KQ1+KQ2+....+KQ12)/12

RCavg = (RC1+RC2+...+RC6)/6

RQavg = (RQ1+RQ2+...+RQ6)/6

If you score more than 50% at the end of course, you will be getting IITBombayX Honour Code Certificate.

This is how these assignments are split across the week,

 - **Section: Learning Objectives**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ1 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ2 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ1 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz-1*)

 - **Section: Active Learning: Think-Pair-Share**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ3 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ4 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ2 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz-2*)

1 Resource Creation Assignment (RC1 in *Resource Creation Assignment-1*)

 - **Section: Peer Instruction**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ5 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ6 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ3 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz-3*)

1 Resource Creation Assignment (RC2 in *Resource Creation Assignment-2*)

 - **Section: Technology Integration - Visualization**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ7 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ8 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ4 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz-4*)

1 Resource Creation Assignment (RC3 in *Resource Creation Assignment-3*)

 - **Section: Assessment**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ9 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ10 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ5 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz*)

1 Resource Creation Assignment (RC4 in *Resource Creation Assignment-4*)

 - **Section: Lesson Plan**

2 Knowledge Quizzes (KQ11 in *Advancing Your Learning* and KQ12 in *Knowledge Quiz*)

1 Reflection Quiz (RQ6 in *Discussion and Reflection Quiz*)

2 Resource Creation Assignment (RC5,RC6 in *Resource Creation Assignment*)

So if you are seeing averages as very less, do not worry because the system looks at the whole and calculates the averages. These averages will increase if you do the corresponding week's activity.

Also the Practice Scores will not be counted for overall grade.

  [1]: https://iitbombayx.in/c4x/IITBombayX/ET601Tx/asset/ET601Tx_-_Course_Handout.pdf

Activity Life-cycle method concept and first app development was explained to students.
TPS activity given to students for “Activity Life-cycle methods concept” of MAD course -

Think Phase (10 mins): Individually student modify First App code to display message when Activity changes state from active to pause and from pause to active.

Pair Phase (5 mins): Discuss the code with your neighbor student and then conclude final code modification in the pair.

Share (5 mins): Students share the code changes in the class and finally with the guidance of teacher code modification concluded.

I created the following TPS activity in the subject - Human Computer Interaction (HCI).

Activity:
Design different screens for a hotel reservation system catering to the following cognitive processes of:
-	Attention
-	Sensory Memory
-	Working memory
-	Long term memory

Think (10 minutes):
Every student needs to list the design features catering to the above cognitive processes.

Pair (20 minutes):
In a group (3 to 4 students), they need first discuss about the design features listed and  sketch the different screens. 

Share (10 minutes):
They need to present their design to the class. Class can suggest/critic on the design.

Students response to TPS activity:
The subject, HCI is concerned with the cognitive psychology for designing the UI (user interface). The concepts from cognitive psychology is new to students of IT. So, they learnt how to design considering the cognitive processes. This activity also helped them to understand how cognitive psychology has implications in UI design.

Interface a standard IEEE-488 parallel bus printer with 8255 and 8086. Draw the necessary hardware scheme required for the same and write an ALP to print a character whose ASCII code is available in AL.

 - Think [5 minutes]: Draw interfacing diagram of standard IEEE-488
   parallel bus printer using 8255 with 8086. And find out the control
   word required for printing a character whose ASCII code is available
   in AL. 
 - Pair [8 minutes]: Discuss control word with your neighbor and
   write Assembly Level Program to print a character whose ASCII code is
   available in AL. 
 - Share [10 minutes]: Compare your program with
   demo.asm program and Participate in discussion of your solution and
   others.

Activity :Matrix initialization and using various operators on matrices was taught. The students were given the task of simple circuit analysis( nodal/ mesh)using the concept of solving system of linear equations in MATLAB.
TPS activity was given to students for “Circuit Analysis using MATLAB”.

Think Phase (10 mins): Individually students have to analyze the given circuit using mesh analysis and then think how to solve the system of obtained equations in MATLAB, and think how to solve these using MATLAB.

Pair Phase (5 mins): Discuss the obtained equations with the neighbor student and then conclude final commands in the pair, to obtain the solution.

Share (10 mins): Students share the commands written, with the class and finally with the guidance of teacher, the  method  is concluded.

Derive the relation for Hall voltage in p-type semiconductor.

Think:Students have to think about formula for Lorentz and electric force and the directions in which they act.

Pair: Check your formulae with your neighbor and equate the two forces to derive the relation for hall voltage.

Share: check your answer with instructor's and answer and share with the class.

All the students actively participated in the activity and most of them around 80% got correct relation. Some students are not able to derive the relation due to following reason:

1. They were not able to recall the formula correctly.

2. Made mistakes in intermediate steps while deriving the relation.

3. Few were absent in previous class when Hall effect was explained.

1) Name of the Topic: Domain Name System (DNS Protocol):
Target Audience: Third Year Computer Science and Engineering Branch
2) Learning objective: 
i) Students can be able to identify the path name of the any domain.
ii) Students will be able to implement DNS client-Server program 
3) Specific TPS questions:
Think phase: If I give DNS topic to students they will think different types of domains and how to create the path name using the concepts of PQDN and FQDN. 
Pair phase: they will make two or three pair of students group for discussing about the above domain concepts
 Share Phase: End of the session all the students will share all the concepts of both PQDN and FQDN with help this concepts they will create any new path name and they are able to identify all types of path names in group.
TPS Avtivity on DNS protocol Concepts 
Students enjoyed the activity and expecting more TPS in future due to clearing the concepts in group activity.

Name of the topic: E-Commerce web application development by using software engineering process model.
Target audience: Third Year – Information Technology Branch Students.

2.
Students can be able to implement small e-commerce web applications based on proper software development life cycle model.

3.
Think-Pair-Share phases:

a. Think Phase:
Students think about
• How to develop e-commerce web applications like amazon, flipkart, ebay etc.
• What is different category of Products can be added on e-commerce web applications.
• Necessary requirements like Software, Hardware, different features or functionality.

b. Pair Phase:
In this phase 2 or 3 Members group is formed and they discussed about the functionality, quality, and user friendly factors of e-commerce applications.

c. Share Phase:
After discussing in Pair, All students shared their ideas and finalized mini project title and the Software process model to use for development of E-commerce web application.

**Subject**: Audio Video Engineering

**Topic**: How compatibility of monochrome and color analog television wrt transmitter and receiver is addressed?

**Think**: Sketches of color and monochrome signals (for one line)were studied.(5 Min)

**Pair**: Neighboring students were encouraged to write what will happen in following situations:(10 Min)

1)Transmission is color TV signal but receiver is Black and White(i.e.) Monochrome TV. 

2) Transmission is monochrome signal but receiver is Color TV.

**Share**: The answers were discussed one by one and corrected by discussions by the instructor.(15 Min)

**Student's Response**: Students were engaged and responsive to discuss different situations of transmitter and receiver issues. It was good learning experience for them.

**Instructor Response**: Instructor also found different thinking ways of students. Almost 90% students participated in the activity happily.
The word understand can be considered in a LO provided it is specified along with appropriate measurable parameters, that help establish the value of "understand".\n

**Course Title:** Fluid Power Systems and Factory Automation
**Topic:** Introduction to basic hydraulic systems and building simple hydraulic circuits
**Teaching procedure followed:**
I taught the students about the basic components required for Hydraulic System. Then they were taught about the basic introductory hydraulic circuit building. 

I exercised TPS activity as below:
**Think Activity:** 
Asked students to build a hydraulic circuit for single acting cylinder (5 min)
Everybody was able to complete within stipulated time and time was adequate.
**Pair Activity:**
Asked students to build hydraulic circuits for different liner actuators (10 min)
Each group has attempted in different way and time was adequate.
**Share Activity:**
Answers were presented by each group and the final correct solution has come up with interactive discussion between students and moderation by the subject teacher.

**Students Involvement:**
Students were found engaged and responsible for their own learning
At the end of the lecture session everybody was found at the same complete knowledge level, mainly due to sharing activity.

**Subject teacher** has observed that how many different ways the students can do a particular thing and due to sharing discussion and moderation students realized their mistakes and were driven to the final correct conclusion/solution with explanation. 100% active involvement was observed.

Here are some possible strategies that you can try to do:

 1. Tell students about the problem. They will cooperate and do TPS more quietly.
 2. Take the support of students for convincing admin that TPS is useful.
 3.  If you have more than one faculty member trying such activities in your college, take their support too in convincing admin.
 4. Invite admin to visit their class and see the engagement level.

And finally if you really want to make an impact, persevere with TPS and write an educational research paper and submit in conferences like IEEE Conference on Technology for Education (T4E). T4E2016 is going to be organized by IIT Bombay. There are lot of teachers within this community who have experience of submission in T4E and some more who are participating regularly in T4E. You may contact them through this forum to know more about T4E. Publication in an International Conference will help you show the importance and effectiveness of what you are doing in class now.

TPS technique is best to use after introducing students to a new topic. TPS allows
the teacher to check their students’ level of understanding before moving deeper into
the subject matter. It also gives students an opportunity to apply what they are
learning, thus making the content more meaningful. Finally, TPS provides a safe
opportunity for students to make mistakes or answer incorrectly without being
penalized by losing points because they did not recognize knowledge gaps in
their learning.

One of the biggest challenges of the think-pair-share is to get all students to truly be engaged. Obviously, instructors hope that they have selected questions that are sufficiently interesting to capture student attention. However, the instructor might also want to consider other ways to increase the likelihood of student participation. The instructor might offer a participation grade somehow tied to a short product students produce from their discussion. Or the instructor can find ways to increase student awareness of the likelihood their group might be called upon to share their answer with the entire class. The instructor might also consider using some of the think-pair-questions on exams and making it clear to students that that is the case.

The think, pair, share strategy is a cooperative learning technique that encourages individual participation and is applicable across all grade levels and class sizes. Students think through questions using three distinct steps:

    Think: Students think independently about the question that has been posed, forming ideas of their own.

    Pair: Students are grouped in pairs to discuss their thoughts. This step allows students to articulate their ideas and to consider those of others.

    Share: Student pairs share their ideas with a larger group, such as the whole class. Often, students are more comfortable presenting ideas to a group with the support of a partner. In addition, students' ideas have become more refined through this three-step process.

Student Focus

1.Topic and Audience: CPU scheduling algorithms,B.Tech second year students
2.Learning Objective: The student will be able to calculate the turn around time for the given set of jobs.
3. TPS Activity:
Think Phase Question: (3-5 Minutes)
Draw a Gantt Chart for the given set of jobs using any Scheduling Algorithm. (Seed Question)

Pair Phase Question: (5-10 Minutes)
Apply various Scheduling algorithms for the given think phase problem and realize their efficiency.

Share Phase Question: (10-12 Minutes)
Let all the peer groups explore their turnaround times for various scheduling algorithms 
Discuss the pros and cons of various scheduling algorithms
Let us all agree upon a best scheduling algorithm

Experiences in PI Design:
1. Making a PI Questionaire using plausible is tough ofcourse but the preparation of sucha PI Activity is encouraging and inquisitive.

Think Phase Question:
Derive a Boolean expression for a given a truth table. ( 3-5 Minutes)

Pair Phase: (5-7 Minutes)
Design a Full adder for addition of 3 bits of binary information using NAND gates.

Share Phase Activity: (10-15 Minutes)
1. Let all the pairs to verify the correctness of their design of the circuit against behavior.
2. Let few groups to talk about their design for their effectiveness interms of the number of gates used.
3. Let all groups realized the importance of designing a circuit with NAND Logic.

S-Share : Ask few students to share answer to problem and from discussion make all aware that how the efficient and correct result comes. (3-4minutes)

Ultrasonic wave travel with velocity
a	 equal to light velocity       
b	more than velocity of sound waves

c	equal to velocity of  sound waves  
d	less than velocity of sound waves

After asking this PI Question in the class i found that most of the students gave ans that it is more than sound waves because they made an assumption that as frequency of ultrasonic waves is more its velocity should be more then i discuss this problem & told students that even if its frequency is more its wavelength is less so ultimately velocity = frequency * wavelength & hence velocity of ultrasonic sound is equal to velocity of sound.

In class having a large student strength with diversified competencies what should be the optimum flow of the course?
Well designed\n
Indeed it is a big problem.

This is a typical problem in an Indian context. One needs to have a Macro to Micro approach within a course. Not only that this principle needs to be also observed in the curriculum design as well. The Fractal Academics being followed in IIT Hyderabad seems to be the near optimum solution in this context. The sequential bookish course flow with a majority class losing interest after few sessions because of the increased complexities happens to be the major challenge before Engineering Education in India.\n

It is suggested that a Two Day Optional Interaction Meeting may be arranged at IIT Bombay to make the course more meaningful in next month. The same can be telecast live using CDEEP infrastructure so that Remote Centres can also participate in it.

Learning Objective: Students Should be able to recall the basics required for correct sketch of the Cartesian Curve & then sketch it.

Peer Instruction Activity: (5 secs)

1) The curve is y^2 = [ x^2 (x+a) ] / (x-a) symmetrical about the  
 
a) line X = 0

b) line Y = O

c) Origin

d) No symmetry

2) The curve y^2 = [ x^2 (x+1) ] / (x-1) has the asymptotes (2 mins)

a) x = -1  and  x = 1

b) x = 1   and  x + y + 1 = 0

c) x + y + 1 = 0 and x = -1

The TPS activity I framed for a session in the course "Advanced Mechanics of solids" is as follows;

Think: Construct an arbitary 3D stress tensor satisfying all its properties.

Pair: Discussing with your neighbour to calculate the corresponding strain tensor assuming the material to be aluminium (Use Design data book for additional data, if necessary).

Share: Discuss the validity of this strain tensor using the Saint Venant's strain compatibility conditions.

PI Question:  XML is a ________________ data.

Answers:  A) Structured  B) Unstructured  C) Semi-structured  D) All of the above E) None of the above.

The above question made the students to think about the characteristics of all the three types of data.  Also, it made them to think about the characteristics of XML.  Finally, based on their level of perception on these types of data, they answered the question.  After initial round of voting, a lot of discussions and deliberations took place among the peers.  Then they agreed upon the characteristics of XML and in final voting, majority of students selected the right answer, Which is C: Semi-structured.

I tried TPS activity for Software Engineering which is the base for many core subjects in all disciplines.
I have given sample projects and students have to design Test case scenario

Think: In think phase of TPS activity, I asked the question to students to find out all possible test cases(5 min).

Pair: In pair phase, each student was asked to pair with the partner, shared their thinking with each other and proceeds with the task. I asked the question related the students’ understanding of the topic. The students were asked to apply all those test cases in sample projects and find out result that they got(10 min).

 Share: In share phase, students shared the solution with the entire class. I discussed how they achieved the concerned result(10 min).

Active Learning from Students:

At the end of the TPS activity, I can able to see the students are encouraged collaboratively, they understand the concepts in deep manner and it increased their self-esteem and participation.

Course: Metrology and Mechanical Measurements. Students from T. E. ( Mech ) class.
Learning objective: Students should be able to design a type of fit for two mating components such as shaft and bush

Topic: Limits fits and tolerances 
Phase I : THINK 
Question i) Select a basic hole with basic size of 40 mm and tolerance grade IT8. Calculate two sizes of the hole. 
You may refer IS code or books or notes. (3 min )
Phase II: Pair phase 
Question ii) Select a suitable type of fundamental deviation of the shaft to achieve a clearance fit with the hole in question no. i). Let the tolerance grade be same IT8. 
You may refer IS code or books or notes. ( 5 min ).

Phase III: Share
Question iii) In relation to the hole and shaft in the previous questions
which designation of fit (combination of hole and shaft) could be optimal for an application where shaft should have a close running ( revolving) fit in the bush. 
You may refer IS code or books or notes. (10-12 min ).

I have implemented in the class. It was very effective. All students participated. However actual time required was more than the designed one.

1.Topic and Audience: CPU scheduling algorithms,undergraduate students
2.Learning Objective: The student will be able to calculate the turn around time for the given set of jobs.
3. TPS Activity:
Think Phase Question: (3-5 Minutes)
Draw a Gantt Chart for the given set of jobs using any Scheduling Algorithm. (Seed Question)

Pair Phase Question: (5-10 Minutes)
Apply various Scheduling algorithms for the given think phase problem and realize their efficiency.

Share Phase Question: (10-12 Minutes)
Let all the peer groups explore their turnaround times for various scheduling algorithms 
Discuss the pros and cons of various scheduling algorithms
Let us all agree upon a best scheduling algorithm

Topic- Discrete Signals and System Classification: 
Signals are basically classified in two types i) Continuous signals (Analog) ii) Digital Signals Amplitude is varying with respect to time is called continuous signal.
Digital Signals are from continuous signals after the process of sampling and quantization.
Other signal classifications are; Deterministic and Random Signals, Periodic and Aperiodic, Even and ODD signals, Energy and Power Signals, Symmetric and Anti-Symmetric etc..

System is basically classified into five types:
i) Linear/Non-Linear
ii)Static/Dynamic
iii)Time-variant/Time In-Variant
iv) Causal/Non-Causal
v) Stable/Unstable

Based the requirements and applications select signals and system and later transfer function is also obtained from the transformation and its ratio.

TPS activity promotes student learning through a sequence of three phases. First, students individually reflect on subject matter, then pair with a partner in class to discuss the information, and finally share ideas from their discussions with the class as a whole. TPS is believed to not only enhance student learning but it also engages all students in discussions, including those who may be more reserved and less likely to share unprompted in class. Instructors may be able to assess how students understand the material by walking around to listen in on various group reflections before then facilitating a larger class discussion. The use of simple online tools, such as Google Drive may provide a platform that facilitates the adaptation of TPS activities. Utilizing Google Docs to facilitate a TPS activity encourages students to take an active role towards investigating a teacher-prompted question in one area, collaborating with peers to add to an electronic document based on the instructor question, and finally projecting their findings on the screen to the larger group.

I have implemented a TPS activity in the class of Group Discussion (GD). The GD topic was : Should GD be a part of any selection process?
Think: I asked the students to think of one reason each for why GD should be a part of any selection process and why it should not be a part of any selection process.
Pair: Then I asked them to pair up with 3 more students to form a group of 4 to discuss and identify the 2 most convincing reasons one for each perspective.
Share: Each group was then asked to share their 2 most convincing reasons one for each perspective.

The entire class enjoyed the exercise thoroughly and each student was involved in it. Moreover they got to know multiple perspectives with proper reasoning. The students found it as an effective pre-GD exercise.

Once students have a firm understanding of the expectations surrounding the strategy, monitor and support students as they work through the steps. 

**Think:**  Teachers begin by asking a specific higher-level question about the text or topic students will be discussing. Students think about what they know or have learned about the topic for a given amount of time (usually 1-3 minutes).

**Pair:**  Each student should be paired with another student. Teachers may choose whether to assign pairs or let students pick their own partner.  Remember to be sensitive to learners' needs (reading skills, attention skills, language skills) when creating pairs.  Students share their thinking with their partner, discuss ideas, and ask questions of their partner about their thoughts on the topic (2-5 minutes).

**Share:**  Once partners have had ample time to share their thoughts and have a discussion, teachers expand the share into a whole-class discussion. Allow each group to choose who will present their thoughts, ideas, and questions they had to the rest of the class.  After the class share, you may choose to have pairs reconvene to talk about how their thinking perhaps changed as a result of the “share” element.

The TPS is really an interesting task to be desined by the teacher. I designed a TPS activity and implemented. The students really were fully engaged without their realization and did enjoy the experience. Some thumb rules which are observed by me in this process, am sharing: 
 - Proper timings assigned for each task
 - think activity should be simple and attemptable by all
 - pair activity be an extension of think activity and doable by 2-3
   students in a group.
 - The share activity is either sharing the solution with class or
   compare the solution strategies with the model solution shown by the
   teacher.

Course Name: Data Communication
Name of the topic: Transmission Impairments. 
Target audience: Second year computer science and engineering. 
Learning objective:
1) Students will be able to identify impairments of the signal in each phase.   
The specific questions: (Multiple choice questions)
Question: Repeaters can be used in Transmission impairments due to ……………..
Options:
A) Increases the signal strength 
B) Decrease the signal strength
C) To maintain the constant level 
D)  Both A and B
E) None of the above

Descriptive type Questions:
The specific questions: How the impairments can happen? And what is the reason? How to recover the attenuated signal?
Answer:  While transmitting the data for longer distance using unguided media some disturbance may happen, for that reason the signal strength may goes down. Due to some disturbance to signal. By using repeaters we can recover the signal strength.

When I tried to conduct a TPS activity in my class of Second Year Engineering on the subject of Strength of Materials, I found that, they started talking to the neighbouring students immediately. Thus, the *pairing stared immediately*, *even when they were asked to think on their own*. But I did not object them, for the reason, because even for sharing their ideas with their fellow students, they need to think first, before they share their ideas with others. Thus I think that, the **'Think Phase' may not exist separately but can be embedded in Pair and Share.**

Dear All;

Please give suggestions and feedback on following TPS Activity.
 
    Name of Topic:  Concept of polynomial root: Number and Existence of Root in a polynomial Equation
    ============================================================
    Target Audience: Second Year Electrical Student
    ============================================================
    Learning Objective: The students will be able to identify the number of real positive and negative roots in a polynomial equation using Descarte's Rule of Sign.
    ============================================================
    TPS Activity: Problem Statement: In a control system Characteristic Equation is given as S^5+S^3+S-1=0. Comment on stability. (Hint: if single root in characteristic equation is positive, then system is unstable)
    ============================================================
    Think: List the various methods to identify the number of real positive, real negative and complex roots [Duration: 3 min].
    Pair: Choose the best method and identify existence of root in above equation with your neighbour. Draft the solution and comment on stability [Duration: 7 min].
    Share: Compare your solutions with instructor’s solution. [Duration: 5 min].
    ============================================================

Gave an TPS activity to Students
1.(Think Phase):Identify the best approach to divide browser window page into two columns and link each other so that left columns link could be opened in the right column.
2. (Pair Phase) Discuss answer with your neighbor who are sitting besides you that whose approach is efficient and easy to implement(students can divide page either with <frameset> tag or <div> tag in HTML.)
3. (Share Phase)Share your solution with class and get to know which is the efficient and easy to implement approach.

Response:  Some of the students implemented above with Frameset tag and others with Div tag and they found out that use of Div tag would be easy to implement as Div tag has far more styles applied to them, re-positioned, hidden etc. with many more robust display capabilities and purposes than frames.

For load forecasting by ANN,
(A)Load bus voltage, Generator bus voltage will be input and output vector respectively and 80% data used for training, 10% for testing and 10% for validation purpose
(B)Variables of load flow analysis will be input and output vectors and 40% data used for training, 30% for testing and 30% for validation purpose
(C)Load bus power, Generator bus power will be input and output vector  and 60% data used for training, 20% for testing and 20% for validation purpose
(D)Power consumed and power generated will be input and output vector  and 70% data used for training, 20% for testing and 10% for validation purpose

**Sample:** Second year students of Computer Science engineering 

**Subject:**  Visual basic 6.0. 

**Topic :** Control and Loop Statements

**Activity :**  As Visual Basic is a programming language and as students were already learnt C language, the topic given for activity was control and loop statements. 
While conducting the activity the multiple choice questions based on medium difficulty level. After conducting the activity immediate feedback was taken. 


**Feedback Analysis:**
68% students had fair knowledge about the loop statements before conducting the peer instruction activity and after conducting the activity 76% students get good knowledge, while 20% get excellent.
We can say that, students learn more in an active learning environment than they do in a passive learning environment.

Course Name: Data Communication
Name of the topic: Transmission Impairments. 
Target audience: Second year computer science and engineering. 
Learning objective:
1) Students will be able to identify impairments of the signal in each phase.
2) Students will be able to use repeaters for recovering the signal strength. 
The specific questions: (Multiple choice questions)
Question: Repeaters can be used in Transmission impairments due to ……………..
Options:
A) Increases the signal strength 
B) Decrease the signal strength
C) To maintain the constant level 
D) Both A and B
E) None of the above

Descriptive type Questions:
The specific questions: How the impairments can happen? And what is the reason? How to recover the attenuated signal?
Answer: While transmitting the data for longer distance using unguided media some disturbance may happen, for that reason the signal strength may goes down. Due to some disturbance to signal. By using repeaters we can recover the signal strength.

**Think-Pair-Share Activity**

**Think** 

Outline one scenario each where client-server and peer-to-peer scenario will be appropriate (2 min)

**Pair**

Discuss the pros and cons of using each of the approaches in the given scenarios (5 min)

**Share**

The teacher gives three scenarios of client-server and one of peer-to-peer, and gives pros and cons of the client-server and peer-to-peer approach, and asks the students to share their answers (15 minutes)
