***Advantage of video:*** The possibility of using Verbal, Visual, and Non-verbal cues in communication (admittedly on 100% powerpoint webinars the non-verbal aspect isn't available).  Overall more flexibility in terms of communication.  Each one of the 3 brings unique benefits to the education process and experience.    

 - Mirror real world.  Replicate real world scenarios better versus
   text, visual, or just audio. 
 - Multi-modality.  This is a user experience & education benefit.
 - Theoretically more engaging.
 - Probably higher perceived value.
 - You might even feel better about the finished product.

***Challenges/Disadvantages of video:***
 - Time allotted.
 - Money/Resources.
 - Time to product/Learning curve of doing multi-media projects.
 
***Advantage of Animation:***

 - Gets and generally keeps peoples' interest for the duration of the animation.
 - Teaches using visual aids, a very strong proven way of learning.
 - You may think this is funny, but it is serious: It gives animators work and helps them learn some science.
 - Helps to explain and illustrate more complex concepts.

***Disadvantage of Animation:***
 - Some people think animations are dumb or for kids and won't pay attention and learn anything.
 - Costs money over traditional teaching methods and requires specialized resources (animators and writers).
 - Ineffective teaching/learning tool for complex interelated concepts due to its inherent simplicity.
 - Can give a false sense of safety as related to science that requires important attention to safety, such as chemistry experiments, electricity and the nuclear fields. Animations are not good for teaching safety in science.

***Advantage of Simulations:*** There are two big advantages to performing a simulation rather than actually building the design and testing it. The biggest of these advantages is money. Designing, building, testing, redesigning, rebuilding, retesting,... for anything can be an expensive project. Simulations take the building/rebuilding phase out of the loop by using the model already created in the design phase. Most of the time the simulation testing is cheaper and faster than performing the multiple tests of the design each time. Considering the typical university budget cheaper is usually a very good thing. In the case of an electric thruster the test must be run inside of a vacuum tank. Vacuum tanks are very expensive to buy, run, and maintain. One of the main tests of an electric thruster is the lifetime test, which means that the thruster is running pretty much constantly inside of the vacuum tank for 10,000+ hours. This is pouring money down a drain compared to the price of the simulation.

The second biggest advantage of a simulation is the level of detail that you can get from a simulation. A simulation can give you results that are not experimentally measurable with our current level of technology. Results such as surface interactions on an atomic level, flow at the exit of a micro electric thruster, or molecular flow inside of a star are not measurable by any current devices. A simulation can give these results when problems such as it's too small to measure, the probe is too big and is skewing the results, and any instrument would turn to a gas at those temperatures come into the conversation. You can set the simulation to run for as many time steps you desire and at any level of detail you desire the only restrictions are your imagination, your programming skills, and your CPU.
***Disadvantage of Simulations:***There are two big disadvantages to performing a simulation as well. The first of these disadvantages is simulation errors. Any incorrect key stroke has the potential to alter the results of the simulation and give you the wrong results. Also usually we are programming using theories of the way things work not laws and theories are not often 100% correct. Provided that you can get your simulation to give you accurate results you must first run a base line to prove that it works. In order for the simulation to be accepted in the general community you have to take experimental results and simulate them. If the two data sets compare, then any simulation you do of your own design will have some credibility. The other large disadvantage is the fact that it is a simulation. Many people do not consider what they do engineering unless they can see, hear, feel, and taste the project. If you are designing a light saber a typical engineer needs to be able to hold the light saber in their hand in order to consider the project worth his or her time. If you are capable of moving your craft into the virtual world of simulations you are no longer restricted by little things like reality. If you want to design a light saber in the virtual world it is not a problem, but in reality that is another matter all together. The virtual world is difficult to get use to the first time you use it for design, but after that the sky isn't even your limit.

***ANIMATION***

**Animation: advantages**
1. Skill and ability Improvement 
2. Interactivity 
3. Engagement 
4. Flexibility and safety 

**Animation: disadvantages**
1.  Many experiments cannot be carried out in the classroom because they are dangerous, and yet learners will need these skills in the workplace. 
2.  Animation programs can represent these dangerous events without the hazards.
3.  If the learner were to make a mistake, the experiment can be repeated without injury.
4.  Real-life experiences are not readily available, but an animated trip in the past brings the learner some feeling of what it must have been like.
5.  The main flexible issue of the animation is to show the non-possible matters in the real-life learning.

***VIDEOS***

**Videos: advantage**
1.Better understanding of the content
2.Precision & clarity that text doesn't have

**Videos:disadvantage**
1.Time allotted.
2.Money/Resources.


***SIMULATION***

**Simulation:advantage**
Simulations can mimic interactions of (geologic) processes, thus helping students understand complex systems behavior.

**Simulation:disadvantage**
No simulation can completely represent/reproduce complex, real world processes.

**Comprehension (Understanding)***type questions increase the students’ ability to summarize and describe in their own words without necessarily relating it to anything.
Key Words: Describe, Distinguish, Explain, Interpret, Predict, Recognize & Summarize*
**Examples:***

**Q1:** Distinguish between Discrete and Digital signals
**Q2:** Explain the concept of sampling and quantization techniqes

  
*Question Framing using Blooms Higher Order*

**Application (Transferring)**
*type questions encourage students to apply or transfer learning to their own life or to a context different than one in which it was learned. 
Key Words: Apply, Compare, Contrast, Demonstrate, Examine, Relate, Solve & Use*
Examples 

Q1: Apply the concept of impulse response 
Q2: Examine the impulse response concept


**Evaluation (Judging)**
*Evaluation questions encourage students to develop opinions and make value decisions about issues based on specific criteria.
Key Words: Assess, Critique, Determine, Evaluate, Judge, Justify, Measure & Recommend*
Examples 

"Q1: Evaluate and justify the the causality concept with an example
**Q2:** Determine the system is Time variant or not
Vdeos advantages and limitations found place in discussion before Reflection quiz.

1) Video:
Advantage - Real life problems may be shown.
Limitation - All types of examples cannot be explained in this method. 

2) Animation:
Advantage - The real life problems which are hard to be exemplified using video, can be represented using animation.
Limitation - Time consuming, and requires enough expertise to create such animations.

3) Simulations :
Advantage - It may explain more critical factors regarding the topic. It is easier to understand
Limitation - Preparation is time consuming and requires specific expertise.

It is evident that the stage at which any assessment technique is applied and the intention broadly categorizes the technique to be under formative or summative assessment, Therefore, by appropriately framing the question, TPS or PI can be used during or at the beginning/ end of any lesson or topic. Thus they can be effectively used as both formative and summative assessments. However, their effectiveness will be lost if they have to be used as summative assessment for the entire course, as course generally consists of many lessons and topics and not necessarily all interconnected

a) Can TPS and PI be used as summative or formative assessment?

Formative Assessment is a part of learning process. It is used to improve learning. Summative Assessment takes place at the end of learning process. So TPS and PI can be used as formative or summative assessment depending upon whether it is used while learning process or at the end of learning process.

b) Within this course where have you seen application of Summative and Formative Assessments?

In this course, formative assessment is covered under LBD activities, Peer Assessments, Self Assessments, discussion Forum and summative assessment is covered in Knowledge Quizzes, Resource Creation Quizzes, Reflection Quizzes and Discussion Forums.

a) Videos
Advantages - Videos like these capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. However having realistic feel is just one of many advantages of using videos. After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those advantages that comes to your mind.
Limitations- Videos are not useful when you want to teach concepts that are not visible to naked eye (like atoms, molecules etc). After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those similar limitations that comes to your mind.
b) Animations
Advantages - Animations like these help us in identifying details like velocity at a given instant which is not usually possible with video alone. However this is one advantage of the many that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many advantages of animations as you can think.

Limitations - Simple animations like these are generally not interactive. However this is one among many limitations that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many limitations of animations as you can think of.

c) Simulations
Advantages - Interactivity is just one of the many advantages. Go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and see how many advantages of simulations are getting listed there. 

Limitations - Use of simulations are generally time-consuming. But there are many other limitations. Post all that is coming to your mind in the discussion forum activity next.

**Advantages of Videos:**  
1) Explanation of concepts in better way  
2) Effective learning and easy recollection of concepts  
**Disadvantages of Videos:**  
1) Not useful for the concepts that are not visualizable  
2) Not interactive  
3) Clarity of picture and sound is required

**Advantages of Animation:**  
1) Detail explanation of topic is possible  
2) Learning is with fun  
3) Understanding and recall of concepts can be better  
**Disadvantages of Animation:**  
1) Less interactive  
2) Difficult to have for each topic  
3) Clarity of picture and sound is required  
4) Sometimes difficult to have hold over the class

**Advantages of Simulations:**  
1) More interactive  
2) Verification of design before implementaion is possible  
**Disadvantages of Simulations:**  
1) Extra cost, time and efforts are required  
2) Software and skill to use it are required  
3) Tells solutions ideally, hence not applicatble to real life actual conditions  
4) Not possible to all type of topics  
5) Student may misuse it by not calculating the parameter first and verifying it later

Ans a) Formative and summative assessment are the evaluation process to know how much student has perceived and actually learnt the topic/subject. TPS and PI can be used for both formative and summative assessment. 
If the questions are appropriately framed TPS or PI can be used either at the beginning or during  or even at the end of any lesson or topic. Thus they can be effectively used as both formative and summative assessments.

Ans b) Within this course application of Summative and Formative Assessments was as follows:
Formative Assessment: LBD activities, Peer assessment,Self assessment,Discussion forum
Summative Assessment: Resource creation quizzes, Knowledge Quizzes, Reflection Quizzes,Discussion forum

Advantages of animation 
1.	a risk-free environment improves learners' skills and abilities.
2.	Interactivity is a mutual action between the learner, learning system, and learning material. 
3.	Adults are very practical learners—they learn better when faced with real problems that have real consequences. 
Disadvantages of animation
1.	Computer animation programs may function well from a technical point of view, but they are difficult to fit into a curriculum.
2.	Requires extensive memory and storage space
Simulation
Advantages:
1.	Forecasting under uncertainty.
2.	Able to answer many questions.
3.	Low cost to implement.
Disadvantages:
1.	Good Theories needs.
2.	No Standardized approach.
3.	Challenging to validate.

All these are modelling tools & are important components of scientific learning-

VIDEOS: Advantages: 

1) Can avail conceptual information & enhances the ability of referring science to real life situations & not only to ideal situations (socks video).

2) Can repeatedly visualize as many times as required & skipped whichever part not required.

VIDEOS: Limitations:

1) Editions cannot be done.

ANIMATIONS: Advantages: 

1) Offers the advantage of delivering better representations of the concepts. 

2) Details can be viewed from angles not feasible in real life.

3) Heips in making invisible things visible.

ANIMATIONS: Limitations:

1) Designing & developing quality animations is quite challenging.

2) Costly & time consuming to make.

SIMULATIONS: Advantages:

1) Improves understanding of the scientific process & contributes to the development of scientific thinking.

2) Investigations , explorations & experimentation of any level & any field can be done. 

SIMULATIONS: Limitations:

1) Unavailability of virtual labs may hamper the advantages of simulations.

2) Must have sound knowledge of software languages.

I support Meera Madam, it is obvious that TPS and PI are good formative assessment methods. But that doesn't mean to be restricted as such because I think TPS generally come up with broader questions that are generally aligned with LO of the course/unit. therefore it can be administered at the end of the course/unit as well making it a summative assessment method.

It is beneficial to teach by using a variety of visualizations like videos,animations and simulations as spoken words are ephemeral. What a student sees remains in his/her mind for a longer time. Use of visuals should be used as per the mindset of the classes around you. But sometimes there are limitations while using visuals as in some cases the concept cannot be cleared through visualizations. Some topics have to be demonstrated through practical methods and interactions  rather than using visualizations.
SIMULATIONS:\nIt can be used when uncertainty is high due to sparse data.\nIt can be used for experimentation in a low-cost, low-risk environment.

a) According to me, TPS and PI can be used as Formative Assessment, as we utilise these tools to assess that how much students have understood the concept. By discussing with their peers in these activities students get immediate feedback about whatever they have learnt.\n\nb)Within our course, the activities where we were involved in discussion forums and then the questions based on such discussions were asked, to asses our understanding gave us the immediate feedback. Hence this is a type of Formative Assessment. The questions which were asked at the end of every unit in the form of Knowledge Quizzes on which we received our final progress grades for those units was the Summative Assessment.
In our course discussion forum activities are similar to TPS and are therefore Formative Assessment.
Summative can also be conducted in the form of Unit Tests at the end of Units where marks are awarded.

If the activity of PI does not carry any marks and conducted during the teaching course as an assessment tool for giving immediate feedback to the students about their learning then it will be formative assessment.

A 90 cm diameter pulley on the line shaft drives a 15 cm diameter pulley, keyed to a dynamo shaft.  Find the speed of dynamo shaft neglecting the slip.
Q.4 (Analyse): If the above compound drive is to be replaced by simple belt drive, what changes you suggest in the diameters of the pulleys ?
Q.5 (Evaluate): If the there will be slip of 2% at each drive in the above (Q3) compound drive, by how much percent reduction in the output speed of dynamo shaft ?

TOPIC : Double slit diffraction

STUDENTS GETTING ASSESSED: First year engg, Mumbai Univ

**RECALL Q.** what do you mean by diffraction of light? 

**UNDERSTAND Q.** When is diffraction of light observable? Explain single slit diffraction pattern.

**APPLY Q**. How is any diffraction pattern formed? Derive intensity equation of double slit diffraction pattern. Hence obtain conditions of pattern.

**ANALYZE Q.** Why are certain fringes in double slit diffraction pattern missing? Explain. Obtain expression for order of missing fringes.

**EVALUATE Q.** What will be the effect on intensity pattern of double slit diffraction,  
1. if I keep slit width the same and increase spacing between slits  
2. if I keep spacing between slits the same and decrease slit width ---describe both

**CREATE Q.** Draw intensity curve on a graph paper using intensity equation for double slit diffraction pattern. Situation is - slit width of both slits= 0.1mm, spacing between slits=0.3mm, distance of screen from slits = 100cm  Light incident on slits is of wavelength 6000Angstorm   Scale on graph paper to be set as    
on x axis 1cm=0.1cm on screen (i.e.distance in the pattern seen on screen e.g. fringe spacing, etc)   & on y axis 1cm = 'I0'/5    ('I0'is maximum intensity in the pattern i.e. intensity of central or 0th fringe)
![the graph to be drawn will look like this][1]

Name of Topic: Convolutional Coding 
Target audience: Third Year E&Tc Engineering students taking Information Theory & Coding Techniques course
Learning Objectives: At the end of the topic the students will be able to
i) Understand the procedure for convolutional coding and decoding
I have decided to use the visualization available at following URL
http://oscar.iitb.ac.in/availableProposalsAction1.do?title=%20Convolutional%20coding%20&id=%20674
(It’s a ppt with animation)
I have planned following active learning strategy
i)	A convolutional encoder is shown to the students and students will be asked to identify the various states the encoder will be in (Think). Then the students can discuss among themselves and can come out with an answer (Pair). Then the next slide is shown to them which has the correct answer which will be discussed (Share). 
ii)	Then the state diagram will be completed step by step using the animation. The animation will be paused before every step so that the students can think and discuss the next step.
iii)	The decoding of convolutional code is also a step by step procedure hence above strategy will be utilized to explain the procedure using the animated example given in the presentation.

The Topic is *Interference of Applied Physics II* of First year Engineering.
Following are the questions set at different levels according to Blooom's Taxanomy.
Please share your views.

**Recall Level:**
Qu.1) What are the conditions of constructive interference and destructive interference in thin film of constant thickness?

**Understand Level**
Qu. 2) Why do you observe multiple colours in soap bubbles?

**Apply Level**
Qu. 3)A parallel beam of light of wavelength 5890 AU is incident on a thin glass plate of refractive index 1.5 such that angle of refraction is 60 deg. Compute the smallest thickness which will appear dark by reflection? 

**Analyse Level**
Qu.4)White light is incident on a soap film at  an angle Sin-1(4/5) and the reflected light on examination by a spectroscope shows dark bands. Two consecutive dark bands corresponding to wave lengths 6.1 x 10-5 cm and 6 x 10-5 cm.coincide.  If the refractive index of the film is 4/3, determine its thickness. 

**Evaluate Level**
Qu.5)A thin film of material of refractive index 1.37 is coated on the surface of a camera lenses one is made up of  flint glass(?=1.54) and another is made up of  glass(?=1.54). Evaluate the smallest thickness of the film  so that the intensity of light reflected by the lens is minimum in both cases. Draw you conclusion.

**Create Level**
Qu. 6)High refractive index plastic materials are available in market for lenses. Design a binocular lens using a material of highest refractive index. Also select a  proper coating material to minimise the intensity of reflected light . Mention the factors taken into consideration for designing the same.

Simulation and Animations have their own advantages and disadvantages\n\nAdvantages of animation 1. a risk-free environment improves learners' skills and abilities. 2. Interactivity is a mutual action between the learner, learning system, and learning material. 3. Adults are very practical learners—they learn better when faced with real problems that have real consequences. Disadvantages of animation 1. Computer animation programs may function well from a technical point of view, but they are difficult to fit into a curriculum. 2. Requires extensive memory and storage space Simulation Advantages: 1. Forecasting under uncertainty. 2. Able to answer many questions. 3. Low cost to implement. Disadvantages: 1. Good Theories needs. 2. No Standardized approach. 3. Challenging to validate.

Advantages:
Video: Realistic, and easy to understand and relate
Animation: Not time consuming and leads to understanding without our own assumption
Simulation: Interactive

Disadvantages:
Video: Cant use for things unseen.
Animation: Not Interactive
Simulation: Time consuming and teachers assistance is required.

Advantages of video's: 
Helps teachers to improve the quality of their work, allowing them to observe and assess their own teaching practices: their attitudes, the quality of their diction, the filer words they use , the time management of their lessons. Also writing with a digital video camera equipped with a foldable screen allows the teacher to record and show immediately to the student the default or good position that is in the centre of a sequence of teaching.

Limitations of video's: It becomes difficult and expensive to do a recording of reasonable quality, considering that these students are very demanding regarding sound quality.

Advantages of animations: Animations seem to offer the advantages of delivering better representations of the concepts. Compared to static images and text, animations can present procedural information (e.g.physiological activities) more explicitly as they show the steps in an orderly manner. Animations surely explain contents more explicitly to students, make students more interested in the subjects taught.

Limitations of animation: Designing and developing quality animations for teaching and learning can be challenging sometimes, people even found no improvement on students learning in using animations in their study.

Advantages of simulations: Instructional simulations can be very effective in stimulating student understanding and it works best when instructor have a clear written statement in the course syllabus about the goals of the simulation and an explanation of how the simulation is tied to the course objectives. Also here active students participation is crucial.

Limitations of simulations: It is very time consuming. Instructor has to provide sufficient time for students to reflect on and discuss what they learnt from the simulation.

Subject: Amorphous Materials
Topic: Glass Melting

Q.1 Remember Level:State the commonly used glass formers, modifiers and intermediates 

Q.2 Understand Level:Explain the role of alkali oxides as modifiers in the glass melting process

Q.3 Apply level: Calculate the amount of raw materials (Na2Co3, Al2O3 and SiO2) for producing 15 Na2O - 5 Al2O3 - 75 SiO2 molar composition.

Q.4 Analyze level:It is quite well known that alkali metals are volatile and that is why if proper care is not taken during melting of glasses containing alkali oxides there is deviation in the stoichiometry of the glass. Various measures to counter such kind of phenomenon include covering the glass melt or reduction in melting temperature or adding excess amount of raw materials considering their volatilization loss during melting. Analyze the underlying mechanisms to compensate for alkali volatilization in each of these cases.

Q.5 Evaluate level: In the question given above which method is the most appropriate to counter alkali volatilization considering its industrial amenability. Explain your rationale in selecting a particular method over its other choices.

Q.6 Create level: A glass tank usually melts 15 Na2O - 10 CaO - 75 SiO2 (wt%) on a continuous basis using Na2CO3, CaCO3, sand and 25% cullet (broken glass of same composition) as raw materials. An engineer by mistake happened to mix raw materials to produce 1000 kg of the above glass on mol% basis i.e. glass of 15 mol% Na2O - 10 mol% CaO - 75 mol% SiO2. Calculate the shortest corrective action.                                                                                                                                                                                             
**Given Data:** Molecular weights (g /mol) of different constituents are: Na2CO3:105.98, CaCO3: 100, SiO2: 60

**Topic**: Process Equipment Design and Drawing

**Unit**: Design of pressure vessel closer based on internal pressure 
(Four closer: flat plate, torispherical, elliptical and hemispherical)

**Target Audience**: Final Year undergraduate Chemical Engineering students

**Learning Objectives**: (1) Students will be able to understand each terms used in the design equation of pressure vessel closer. (2) Students will be able to design pressure vessel closer based on internal pressure. (3) Students will be able to study effect of various parameters on thickness of pressure vessel closer (4) Students will be able to select best closer for given condition based on least amount of material required for the fabrication.

**Question set for Resource Creation Assignment**:

**Recall**: Write equations for calculation thickness of all the four type of closers based on inside diameter of the cylindrical vessel.

**Understand**: can you convert above equations in the form where outside diameter of cylinder is given for design?

**Apply**: For a given condition of Temperature, pressure, diameter, welded joint efficiency factor and material of construction, calculation thickness of each of the four type of closer.

**Analysis**: If the value of joint efficiency factor is increased, what will be its effect on thickness of each closer in terms of percentage savings of material of construction?

**Evaluate**: For conducting saponification reaction in a pressure vessel at given condition of temperature and pressure, one has to design top and bottom closer. Based on temperature and corrosiveness, selection two different MoC and calculate thickness of elliptical and torispherical closer and compare their weights.

**Create**: Design and compare elliptical closer with that of torispherical closer for a heat exchanger used for condensation of benzene using water. For this purpose based on boiling point of benzene at design pressure select suitable material of construction. Also keep corrosive resistance in mind while selecting the material of construction. Compare the result of both type of closers in terms of total weight of closer and cost of material of construction.

(1)	Videos
Advantages: Videos facilitate thinking, it can be rewind to review the key concepts and visuals are always interesting and realistic.

Limitations: Videos are time taking process to prepare and create, computer skills are required for the same. These are not useful for invisible elements.

(2)	Animation
Advantages: Helps to demonstrate things visually in 2D or 3D, it takes less time to learn about complex concepts when compared with traditional classroom teaching. Details demonstration is possible.

Limitations: It requires knowledge of using graphics, software and programming skills to prepare and may not fit into curriculum always. This cannot be an interactive session.

(3)	Simulation
Advantages: It provides best theory to develop, helps to bridge gap between theory and practice. This provides interactive session.

Limitations: It may not be an appropriate for every learning objective, it is very challenging to validate. The process is very time-consuming.

Videos, animations and simulations are effective methods for teaching if used and presented in a proper way.

Videos  

Advantages

1.	Increases the interest of learner’s, makes the learning process more enjoyable and retains the student’s interest for longer period of time.

2.	It has been proved that visuals are always interesting and engaging than reading through pages after pages. Hence, videos can keep students engaged in the course. 
3.	Videos are mostly very demonstration-friendly. 
4.	 Students who are good visual learners will be having lot of advantages studying from videos. They can store information easily. 
5.	The training time is reduced to a great extent using videos.
6.	Videos like these capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. However having realistic feel is just one of many advantages of using videos. After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those advantages that comes to your mind.

Limitation

1.	There is no direct contact between the teacher and the learner so clarification of doubts will take some time.
2.	Using videos in e-learning courses can be expensive and time-consuming, for you have to spend money and hire people to script, edit and create the video.
3.	Playing video can use a lot of bandwidth and take time to load. 
4.	If the video created does not match up the standards of a high quality video, then it can be distracting instead of useful. 
5.	There might be problem housing the video in case, you are unable to upload or embed videos directly as allowed by most of the learning management system.
6.	Videos are not useful when you want to teach concepts that are not visible to naked eye (like atoms, molecules etc). After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those similar limitations that comes to your mind.


Animation :

Advantages

1. Animations help in conveying information quickly and effectively to learners.
2. Animations like these help us in identifying details like velocity at a given instant which is not usually possible with video alone. However this is one advantage of the many that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many advantages of animations as you can think.

Limitation

1. Requires special equipment for a quality presentation and cannot depict actuality like video.
2. Simple animations like these are generally not interactive. However this is one among many limitations that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many limitations of animations as you can think of.

Simulation :

Advantage

1. Helps in studying the behavior of a system without building it and even helps in performing analysis with experimentation.

2. Interactivity is just one of the many advantages. Go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and see how many advantages of simulations are getting listed there.

Limitation

1.	Expensive to build a simulation model and as simulations portray the real situations in simple way sometimes it becomes very complex and difficult to prepare a simulation model.
2.	Sometimes it is difficult to interpret the simulation results. 
Use of simulations are generally time-consuming. But there are many other limitations. Post all that is coming to your mind in the discussion forum activity next.

Topic: Writing a formal Report - At the end of the unit students will be able to write any report.

Revised Bloom's Taxonomy six Levels: Recall, Understand, Apply, Analyse, Evaluate & Create

**Recall**:Identify formal reports? Give six(6) printed reports both formal and informal and ask them to identify formal reports out of the given)
**Understand**: Students are given strips of a (jumbled) formal report which they have to put in right order.
**Apply**: Give pictures/Situations to form a questionnaire to gather information for a report.
**Analyse**: Segregation of the information gathered with the help of a questionnaire and represent it using graphs/charts.
**Evaluate**: Give students an assignment of writing a report on the information given in the form of graphs and charts and some additional inputs.
**Create**: Write a detailed report on any given topic.

**I think option C is correct because**

(a)	LOs are set such that it should focus on the course contents considering the broader view of the course 
(b)	As per revised Bloom’s taxonomy, LOs should follow the lower order from Recall-Understand-Apply 
(c)	Also as per COs should follow the higher order from Analyze-Evaluate-Create which is further to the lower order.

**Option A is wrong because**
(a)	LOs give idea to the students that- why they have to study the given topic and what are the expected outcome.
(b)	Only picking of right action verb does not means that the LO is specific and measurable
(c)	The LO may not be well conceived and appropriate to the requirement

**Option B is wrong because** 
(a)	The student should progress of from lower order to higher order.
(b)	As per revised bloom’s taxonomy Recall-Understand-Apply activity is lower order and Analyze-Evaluate-Create is of higher order activities and higher order activities should not be considered while framing LOs

Topic :Virtual Memory

Learning Objective: Analyze the dynamic memory allocation using paging concept

Url for visualization: http://oscar.iitb.ac.in/availableProposalsAction1.do?title=%20Virtual%20Memory%20&id=%20567

Active Learning Stratergy: TPS and PI can be used as active learning strategies.

1.Before starting the video mention the Learning Objective for the topic to the students.

2.After playing the video which delivers the contents regarding the construction of page table pause the video.

3.Here conduct a TPS activity for creating a page table for different scenario.

4.Resume the video and complete the topic regarding the mapping of the pages from virtual memory to the main memory pause the video.

5.Here conduct a TPS activity for mapping the process from virtual memory to main memory for a different scenario.


6.Resume the video and complete the video.

7.And after completion of the video conduct a PI for listing out the difficulties in creation of page table using paging technique.

The topic selected is *Diffraction* of Applied Physics

The learning objective : Students should be able to explain the effect of slit width on width of principle maxima of single slit diffraction pattern. They should explain the presence of maxima and minima within principle maxima of double slit diffraction pattern. 

URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9D8cPrEAGyc

The strategy is ***Observe, Explain and Discuss***

Play video to show single slit diffraction , ask students to write their observation about the effect of variation of slit width on width of maxima of the diffraction pattern.

Share the observation with partner.

Then discuss the effect by asking questions to different pairs.

Play remaining video to show diffraction at double slit.

Ask students to write their observation about principle maxima of diffraction pattern.

Allow them to share the observation with partner.

Then discuss how maxima and minima are observed within principle maxima of double slit diffraction pattern.

**Advantages** : - All these techniques make a lecture interesting, removes monotonous feel of traditional lecture and helps students to grasp in depth about the topic. 

1.	**Videos** 		: Visualization of realistic situation ready to show along with sound
2.	**Animations**	: Visualization ready to show, intermediate parameter values can be shown easily through simple graphics, no actual actions to be recorded, micro-detailing can be shown
3.	**Simulations**	: Visualization ready to show, intermediate parameter values can be shown easily through simple graphics, no actual actions to be recorded, micro-detailing can be shown, interactive mode allows all sorts of parameter variation cases demonstrated easily, MORE SUITABLE FOR LABORATORY SESSIONS/BATCHWISE SESSIONS

**Limitations** :-  Not all topics to be taught, can be demonstrated with these techniques support. Also whenever these techniques are used they must be able to fill in the gaps of traditional demonstrations in class & students’ grasping of that topic. If that purpose is not served, the techniques can turn into a flop show for the instructor.

1.	**Videos**		: No interactive responses, actual actions/happening only can be recorded, intermediate parameter insertions is tedious job
2.	**Animations**	: No interactive responses, narrations to be added if required, large designing efforts 
3.	**Simulations**	: Time consuming due to interactive modes, not suitable for class demonstrations, huge designing efforts

Course-Communicative English
Topic- Learning to write a basic paragraph
Objective- Learners will be able to write basic paragraphs by the end of the lesson.
Level- B.Tech 1st semester
Strategy- Video, TPS & PI will be used
URL-https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_pZWdF7ujA

Steps:

First, students will be put in pairs, to discuss the rules of writing a basic paragraph
Then they will share they ideas with the class. Then the teacher will show the video and ask the comprehension questions based on video by pausing the video.
Then the teacher will show the rest of the video.
Then the students will be asked to discuss with a partner and gather about a given topic.
Then they will write a basic paragraph on the given topic.

Videos, animations and simulations are effective methods for Effective teaching 

A)Videos : 

Advantages : 
1) We can repeatedly visualize as many times as required & skipped whichever part not required Can be stopped at any time.

2) Easy understanding of even a difficult concept 

3) Visualization of realistic situation.

4) Simple as compared to simulation and animation


 Limitations: 
1) Cant make invisible things visible 

2) Not active learning interaction

3) not cover each every concept cover in text book

B)Animations:
Advantage : 

1) Make invisible things visible 

2) Better internal visualization, understanding of difficult concepts 
 

Limitations:
1) One has to see and gather all the internal details of process and model. 

2) Not active learning interaction

3) Large designing efforts, Takes time for designing 



C)Simulations 
Advantage: 

1) helps in setup virtual environment of model and process 

2) It is Interactive

3) Parameters of model can be analyze 

4) Save actual cost and time for setup the actual experimental environment.

5) Real life parameters can setup easily in virtual environments


Limitations: 

1) Simulation does not produce optimum results

2) Difficult to design.

3) Time consuming for designing

3) Costly

**Advantages of videos:** 
•	Theoretically more engaging than simple lectures. 
•	Precision & clarity with visual and audio that text doesn't have. 
•	Demonstrations become easier.
•	More retention volume and period of the students
•	It has the option to stop, start and rewind hence each video and hence ask students to predict the outcome of a demonstration, and elaborate on, or debate a point.

**Disadvantages of videos:** 
•	More Money/Resources required than lectures. 
•	Video is linear by nature and hence cannot go back to a specific point later.

**Advantages of animation:** 
•	 Engaging
•	Helps to explain and illustrate more complex concepts. 
•	Show prototype designs 
•	Showing processes or relationships not usually visible

**Disadvantages of animation:** 
•	Costs money over traditional teaching methods and requires specialized resources (animators and writers). 
•	Simple and hence ineffective teaching/learning tool for complex interelated concepts. 
•	Too much animation on a page can be distracting and even annoying - for example too
•	Some information of real-life learning will be lost in the animation program. 
•	Cannot depict actuality like video

**Advantages of simulation :** 
•	Study the behavior of a system without building it. 
•	Results are accurate in general, compared to analytical model. 
•	Helps to find unexpected phenomenon, behavior of the system. 
•	Easy to perform ``What-If'' analysis. 

**Disadvantages of simulation :**
•	Expensive 
•	Sometimes it is difficult to interpret the simulation results.

Simulations, animations and video etc, are important ingredients of educational technology (ET) that provides constructive support to address the due-change in instructional strategy.
 ----------
As stated above in forum that if all the knowledge is available in recorded form, why do we need a teacher? 

As per my knowledge, it is the **information** recorded in the form of database and not the **knowledge**. There are various topics/ subjects that have no application of ET in either of the form. 

----------
The question of replacing a teacher with ET does not arise, unless we have application of knowledge base technology (KB) - a functional part of artificial intelligence (AI) system, in implementing any sort of instructional strategy in place of a teacher. In my view, there is no such application at all of **Artificial Intelligence** till date. Thenceforth, the need to have teacher, more appropriate to term as **Facilitator**,  shall remain so.

TOPIC : Double slit diffraction

STUDENTS GETTING ASSESSED: First year engg, Mumbai Univ

**RECALL Q.** what do you mean by diffraction of light?

**UNDERSTAND Q.** When is diffraction of light observable? Explain single slit diffraction pattern.

**APPLY Q.** How is any diffraction pattern formed? Derive intensity equation of double slit diffraction pattern. Hence obtain conditions of pattern.

**ANALYZE Q.** Why are certain fringes in double slit diffraction pattern missing? Explain. Obtain expression for order of missing fringes.

**EVALUATE Q.** What will be the effect on intensity pattern of double slit diffraction, 
1. if I keep slit width the same and increase spacing between slits 
2. if I keep spacing between slits the same and decrease slit width ---describe both

**CREATE Q.** Draw intensity curve on a graph paper using intensity equation for double slit diffraction pattern. Situation is - slit width of both slits= 0.1mm, spacing between slits=0.3mm, distance of screen from slits = 100cm Light incident on slits is of wavelength 6000Angstorm Scale on graph paper to be set as 
on x axis 1cm=0.1cm on screen (i.e.distance in the pattern seen on screen e.g. fringe spacing, etc) & on y axis 1cm = 'I0'/5 ('I0'is maximum intensity in the pattern i.e. intensity of central or 0th fringe)

Advantages :

 Learners take less time to learn complex things through animation 

  Animation makes learner enjoy more to learn difficult things. 

  Many experiments cannot be carried out in the classroom because they are dangerous, and yet learners will need these skills in the workplace. Animation programs can represent these dangerous events without the hazards.

  Learners have more interaction with the content and are thus more likely to assimilate the knowledge, skills and concepts involved .

Limitations :

Some information of real-life learning will be lost in the animation program.

Animation does not take into account and consideration different student levels  within a group or class

Takes a lot of effort to create even a basic animation

Too much animation on  can be distracting .

Advantage :

System study can be done without building actual hardware model.

As compared to analytical model , results are accurate in general.

It helps to find unexpected behavior of the system.

"What-If" analysis is easy to perform.

Limitations:

Expensive to build a simulation model.

Sometimes it is difficult to interpret the simulation results.

Challenging to validate results of simulation

**Recall Level**: Define the IF function

**Understand Level**: Explain the various parts of IF function - IF(Logical_Test, Value_if_True, Value_if_false)

**Apply Level**: Able to use IF function to compare the variable value with preset value

**Analyze Level**: After comparing the outcome of apply level, will be able to categorize value within predefined categories - categorized the students on their final exam score

**Evaluate Level**: Able to compare the various outcomes - Judge the pass and fail percentage of students in class along with their division

**Create Level**: Able to develop the application of IF function in real life scenario - Optimal use of resource for profit optimization

OBJECTIVES articulate the knowledge and skills you want students to acquire by the end of the course
ASSESSMENTS allow the instructor to check the degree to which the students are meeting the learning objectives
INSTRUCTIONAL STRATEGIES are chosen to foster student learning towards meeting the objectives

Video: Help the  students to  gain attention and maintain student interest in the theories and concepts under discussion. Students can see the theories and concepts in action. In more than a figurative sense, theories and concepts leap from the screen.
 Limitation : Students do not approach visuals with a sufficiently critical eye.

Animation:  As compared to video invisible details can be added to improve learning
Limitation: Not interactive lack of hands on practice

Limtation: No simulation can completely represent/reproduce complex, real world processes

(c) they will be able to utilize tabulated results to analyse the yield of float and sink along with their ash content. (d) they will be able to predict the poor, good or best washability performance/ deficiency of given sample.

Question set for resource creation assignment:

Recall: write equations for evaluation of yield of float and yield of sink with their ash content.

Understand: convert the given tabulated results of float and sink analysis as per various given specific gravity of washing medium.

apply: for given specific gravity and sample evaluate the total percentage of clean coal with its ash and total percent of sink with its ash.

Analysis: plot the details with respect to specific gravity of yield of clean coal and sink and analyze and behavior of curve.

evaluate: the behavior of three type of curves including total float ash curve, total sink ash curve and washbaility characteristics curve will be used to predict the sample washbility.

create: compare the separation of clean coal with dirt and mineral matter using various specific gravity separating medium. evaluate the best performance of separation using selected separating medium which provides optimum percentage of yield for clean coal.

Topic: Environmental Engineering
Unit: Gaussian Plume behavior model
Target Audience: Pre final year undergraduate Chemical Engineering Students
Learning Objectives: (i) Students will be able to understand each terms of the Gaussian Plume behavior model (ii) Students will be able to find concentration of air pollutant at specified distance (iii) Students will be able to understand application of model with necessary modifications in basic equation for different criteria like point source , line source and area source. 
Question set for Resource Creation Assignment:
RECALL: Idea about the various environmental conditions like stable, unstable or neutral condition.

UNDERSTAND: Try to understand each term of the model equation
APPLY: for a given environmental condition, find concentration of air pollutant at various distance based on type of model equation.

ANALYSIS: Try to calculate at what distance, concentration of air pollutant is under given or proscribed norms.

EVALUATE: For given set of environmental condition, find dispersion coefficient and use the value to predict the concentration of air pollutant for point source, line source and area source. Also measure actual data and try to compare the practical value with model predicted value.

CREATE: If practical value is not matching with model predicted value, suggest modification factor or correction in the given equation.

**Topic** – Interfacing of 8251 (USART) and 8086

**Recall** – Specify the mode word format required to initialize 8251 in asynchronous mode for the following condition (i) Baud rate factor x 1 (ii) Character length 5 bits (iii) No parity (iv) 1 stop bit

**Understand** - Design the hardware interface circuit for interfacing 8251 with 8086.

**Apply** - Set the 8251 in asynchronous mode as a transmitter and receiver with even parity enabled, 2 stop bits, 8-bit character length, frequency 160 kHz and baud rate 10 K.

**Analyze** - Determine among asynchronous and synchronous mode which one is better for long distant serial communication.

**Evaluate** – Evaluate the performance of 8251 with respect to speed and accuracy of data transmitted.

**Create** - (a) Write an ALP to transmit 100 bytes of data string starting at location 2000:5000H. (b) Write an ALP to receive 100 bytes of data string and store it at 3000:4000.

Advantage :
Theoretical background will be more clear by video presentation.
Limitation :
the query of the students on the fly will not be clear by this method.

Advantage :
All possible values about the problem will be more explored by this method.
Limitation :
Students may not solve much of the problem at their own and rely on the animation.

Advantage :
Both the theoretical and problem solving skill will clear by this methods.
Limitation :

Topic of visualization: Meissner effect

Type of Knowledge: Concept

Learning Objectives that you want to achieve with the use of this visualization: Students must be able to predict the outcome of meissner effect and apply this concept in solving problems and designing instruments.

Active Learning Strategy: 
Observe phase: I will first play the first part of the video which consists of cooling the disc below the superconducting temperature in the presence of magnetic field.Then I will pause the video at this point.
Predict phase: I will ask the students to discuss amongst themselves and predict the outcome of the experiment. 
Discuss phase:Play the remaining part of the video, discuss the result and point out some possible applications.

Disadvantages: not interactive, at times students are not able to conceive the larger picture.

Simulations:
Advantages: increases interactivity, helps in grabbing attention of class, helps in analyzing and evaluating the concepts learned
Disadvantages: time consuming

**a) Videos** 

**Advantages** - Videos like these capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. However having realistic feel is just one of many advantages of using videos. After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those advantages that comes to your mind. 

**Limitations**- Videos are not useful when you want to teach concepts that are not visible to naked eye (like atoms, molecules etc). After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those similar limitations that comes to your mind. 

**b) Animations** 

**Advantages** - Animations like these help us in identifying details like velocity at a given instant which is not usually possible with video alone. However this is one advantage of the many that you can share. **Limitations** - Simple animations like these are generally not interactive. However this is one among many limitations that you can share. **c) Simulations** 

**Advantages** - Interactivity is just one of the many advantages. Go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and see how many advantages of simulations are getting listed there.

**Limitations** - Use of simulations are generally time-consuming. But there are many other limitations. Post all that is coming to your mind in the discussion forum activity next.

Advantages of Videos: 
1) Explanation of concepts in better fashion
2) Effective learning and easy recollection of concepts
3) videos can be stopped during the lecture and concepts can be discussed with students for few minutes
 Limitations of Videos: 
1) Not interactive 
2) Clarity of picture and sound is required
3) Not useful for the concepts that are difficult to visualize
4) Students may loose interest if video is not audible or not visible for backbenchers 

Advantages of Animation: 
1) Detail explanation of topic is possible 
2) creates interest  in students 
3) Helps to demonstrate things visually in 2D or 3D
3) Understanding and recall of concepts can be better 
Limitations of Animation: 
1) Less interactive 
2) Difficult to make animations on each topic of the syllabus. It requires knowledge of using graphics, software and programming skills to prepare. 
3) Clarity of picture and sound is required 

Advantages of Simulations: 
1) Builds a system and easy to understand to digest working. 
2) More interactive 
3) Verification of design before implementation is possible 
4) Makes topics more visible, appealing and interesting for students 

limitations of Simulations: 
1) Expensive, time and efforts are required 
2) Software and skill to use/programming tools  are required. 3) Tells solutions ideally, hence not applicable to real life actual conditions 
4) Not possible to all type of topics 
5) Student may misuse it by not calculating the parameter first and verifying it later
valid points.. nice compilation.

Videos:
Videos can be created for theory subjects.  This will help the students to understand the theory.  However, the success of the videos depends upon the efficiency of the teachers demonstrating the lectures.

Animations:
Animations can be used for solving problems i.e. in general for problematic subjects.  This will help the students to understand the steps used in solving the problems.  However, creating good animations is in the hands of good Animators.  

Simulations:
Simulations can be used for Practical Subjects.  This will help the students to apply various range of inputs and get the required outputs.  However, creating effective Simulations requires a lot of programming skills.

Course: **Power System Operation and Control**
==================================================================================
Topic: **Steady State Stability**
==================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Recall**
Q1: Define steady state stability and steady state stability limit.
==================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Understand**
Q2: According to P-delta curve steady state stability limit occurs is ___________ which occurs at delta=________degree. 
==================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Apply**
Q3: A single machine is connected to infinite bus through 0.2pu reactance. If infinite bus voltage and emf induced in synchronous generator 1 pu.  Determine steady state stability limit of synchronous generator.
=================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Analyze**
Q4: A single machine having 0.2pu reactance is connected to infinite bus through a transmission line of reactance 0.3pu. If a transmission line is added in parallel with existing transmission line with same reactance, determine the effect on steady state stability limit.
=================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Evaluate**
Q5: A single machine having 0.2pu reactance is connected to infinite bus through a transmission line of reactance 0.3pu. To increase power transfer capability of transmission line by (a) 20% (b) 50%, evaluate the size of capacitive reactance to be added in series with transmission line.
=================================================================================
Cognitive Level: **Create**
Q6: Maharashtra State Electricity Board have excessive power of 1500MW. The power demand of Gujarat  State from Maharashtra at various times are as follows
(i)	6.00am to 10.00 am-----1000MW
(ii)	10.00am to 2.00pm-----1500MW
(iii)	2.00pm to 6.00pm-----1000MW
(iv)	6.00pm to 8.00pm------500MW
The tie line connected between Gujrat and Maharastra have maximum power transfer capability of 1500MW. To keep load angle delta constant at 30 degree, give the possible solutions to fulfill Gujarat Demand according to time.
=================================================================================

**a) Videos** 

**Advantages** - Videos like these capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. However having realistic feel is just one of many advantages of using videos. After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those advantages that comes to your mind. 

**Limitations**- Videos are not useful when you want to teach concepts that are not visible to naked eye (like atoms, molecules etc). After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those similar limitations that comes to your mind. 

**b) Animations** 

**Advantages** - Animations like these help us in identifying details like velocity at a given instant which is not usually possible with video alone. However this is one advantage of the many that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many advantages of animations as you can think.

**Limitations** - Simple animations like these are generally not interactive. However this is one among many limitations that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many limitations of animations as you can think of.

**c) Simulations** 

**Advantages** - Interactivity is just one of the many advantages. Go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and see how many advantages of simulations are getting listed there.

**Limitations** - Use of simulations are generally time-consuming. But there are many other limitations. Post all that is coming to your mind in the discussion forum activity next.

Video: 
The possibility of using Verbal, Visual, and Non-verbal cues in communication, overall more flexibility in terms of communication. Mirror real world.  Replicate real world scenarios better versus text, visual, or just audio.
Video limitation depend on size and length
Simulation:
One of the primary advantages of simulators is that they are able to provide users with practical feedback when designing real world systems. This allows the designer to determine the correctness and efficiency of a design before the system is actually constructed.
Limitation: Computer simulation cannot react to unexpected 'sub-goals' which the student may develop during a learning-process. These sub-goals would be brought up during a teacher-student interaction but they remain unsaid during the individual student use of a simulation.
Animation:
They are simple to make using an animation program and a series of images
Do not require your web browser to have a plug-in
GIFs are easy to use when creating a webpage
Limitation of computer animation is in the area of motion. While animators are quite good at creating a single-frame pose for a character, they are not as good at creating realistic motion across frames.
Another limitation of computer animation is that it does not stand up well to full lighting within the program. This means that for CGI characters to seem realistic, they need to be shown in near twilight or almost dark conditions.

**video's**: Advantages: it is realistic and effective way of teaching. Helps teachers to have the time management of their lessons. They are self explanatory.

             Limitations :  it requires good technical support in the class.It becomes difficult and expensive.it is difficult to locate for every topic.

 **Animations**:Adv:Helps in recalling concepts. Animations seem to offer the advantages of delivering better representations of the concepts. More explicitly as they show the steps in an orderly manner. Animations surely explain contents more explicitly to students, make students more interested in the subjects taught.

               Limitations: Designing and developing quality animations for teaching and learning can be challenging sometimes.

**simulations**: Adv:Instructional simulations can be very effective and interactive in  understanding and it works best when instructor have a clear written statement in the course syllabus. Also here active students participation is crucial.

                Limitations : It is very time consuming. Instructor has to provide sufficient time for students to reflect on and discuss what they learnt from the simulation.it is complex to make and costly as well.
The second set of tools are appropriate for SA while TPS and PI are appropriate for FA

Visualization or visualization (see spelling differences) is any technique for creating images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message. Visualization through visual imagery has been an effective way to communicate both abstract and concrete ideas since the dawn of man. Visualization today has ever-expanding applications in science, education, engineering (e.g., product visualization), interactive multimedia, medicine, etc. Typical of a visualization application is the field of computer graphics. the most important development in visualization since the invention of central perspective in the Renaissance period

Sub: Strength of Materials, 
Topic: Columns
Target audience: Second year B.tech Mechanical Engineering Students.
Learning Objective: by the end of this unit, students will be able to 
1. Classify columns based on geometry and end conditions
2. State Euler's and Rankine and Secant formula for Columns.
3. Calculate maximum load that a column can withstands.
4. Design columns to withstand a particular load.

Questions in different levels of Revised Bloom's Taxonomy are:

1. Recall: State Euler's theory for long columns. (1 marks)

2. Understand: Explain the concept of effective length and how it determines the strength of a column? (2 marks)

3. Apply: A 2m long pin-ended column of square cross section is to be made of wood. Assuming E= 13GPa, yield stress= 12MPa and using a factor of safety of 2.5 in computing Euler's critical load for buckling. Determine the size of this cross section if the column is to safely support a load of (a) 100 kN (b) 200 kN.(4 marks)

4. Analyze: Examine a round column of diameter 0.15m and of length 2m made of RCC fixed at both ends.  What are the theories one should use to determine the critical load of this column? Why? (6 marks)

5. Evaluate: Which type of columns(of same material and geometry) have the capability to withstand maximum load assuming the column to be long. (Use appropriate formula)
Columns (a) pivoted at both ends (b) fixed at both ends (c) One end fixed and the other end free (d) One end fixed and the other end hinged (8 marks)

6. Create: Design a RCC column (fixed at both ends) to withstand a load of 10 MN and of a length of 5m with a factor of safety 2. (Use design data book if necessary) (10 marks)

TOPIC:- INTERFERENCE
The different cognitive level of questions from Recall to Create level for this topic are given below: 
1. Recall:- Define the phenomenon of interference of light and principle of superposition. 
2. Understand:- Distinguish between the division of amplitude and division of wave front method of interference.
3. Apply:-  Find the wavelength of sodium light by using Newton's ring method.
4. Analyze:- Analyze the formation of circular fringes in Newton's Ring method. 
5. Evaluate:- Evaluate the fringe width between two consecutive bright or dark rings.
6. Create:- Design a model to illustrate the phenomenon of interference.

(1) Improves learning 
(2) Engaging (supports active learning)
(3) Interative
(4) Consistent (all leaners learn same principles and skills)
(5) Practical
(6) Modular

I think that videos help in aiding active learning. However, they have limitations when encountering complex problems and invisible elements.
Animations also help in active learning.  They can go a step ahead compared to videos, since they can show invisible elements. However, they are time taking to be made for complex problems.

Limitations:
(1) Requires special equipment for a quality presentation
(2) The explanation of the teacher will only depend on the video and not on his/her experience. 
(3) Time consuming
(4) Expensive
(5) Technical support required
Simulations are interactive.  They can be used to understand complex problems.  However, they are time consuming for interaction.

Course Title: Production Processes
Name of the Topic: Selection of suitable dead center  
Target Audience: Second Year B. Tech. Production Students (60)

Recall: List the various types of dead centers.
1.	Ordinary center
2.	Ball center
3.	Insert type of center
4.	Half center
5.	Friction less center
6.	Tipped center

Understand: Identify the different components of dead center and understand working.

Apply: Selection of suitable dead center for the given work piece. 

Analyze: considering the dimensions of the work piece and accuracy of the work piece required, select the suitable dead center amongst dead centers available. 

Evaluate: consider the work surface to be used for clamping. Then see the dimensions of the work piece and clamping force required. Accordingly select the suitable dead center. 

Create: For a heavy job to be machined at high speed on lathe machine, select the suitable dead center out of the available in the workshop.

**Advantages** - Videos like these capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. However having realistic feel is just one of many advantages of using videos. After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those advantages that comes to your mind. 

**Limitations**- Videos are not useful when you want to teach concepts that are not visible to naked eye (like atoms, molecules etc). After going through the animation and simulation, go to the discussion forum and post all those similar limitations that comes to your mind. 

**b) Animations** 

**Advantages** - Animations like these help us in identifying details like velocity at a given instant which is not usually possible with video alone. However this is one advantage of the many that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many advantages of animations as you can think.

**Limitations** - Simple animations like these are generally not interactive. However this is one among many limitations that you can share. Continue going through the visualization example of simulation and then go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and post as many limitations of animations as you can think of.

**c) Simulations** 

**Advantages** - Interactivity is just one of the many advantages. Go to the discussion forum activity (next one) and see how many advantages of simulations are getting listed there.

**Limitations** - Use of simulations are generally time-consuming. But there are many other limitations. Post all that is coming to your mind in the discussion forum activity next.

**Topic**: Numerical Methods for Chemical Engineering
**Unit**: Dynamic Simulation of Distillation Column using Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE) solvers 
**Target Audience**: Pre final year undergraduate Chemical Engineering Students 
**Learning Objectives**: (i) Students will be able to understand various ODE solvers such as Euler’s method, Runge – Kutta Method, Adams – Bashforth techniques using MATLAB (ii) Students will be able to simulate distillation column model using various ODE solvers (iii) Students will be able to understand the dynamic behavior of distillation column under various inputs (iv) Students will be able to understand the effect of step size on numerical solutions obtained by various ODE solvers. 
**Question set for Resource Creation Assignment:** 
**RECALL**: Write equations of various ODE solvers such as Euler’s method, Runge-Kutta method, etc.
**UNDERSTAND**: Try to understand each term of the ODE solvers such as step size, error term etc. and also try to learn how to use MATLAB for numerical solution of ODEs. 
**APPLY**: For a given distillation column system along with initial condition, simulate distillation system  using various ODE solvers available in MATLAB and obtain dynamic behavior using different step sizes.
**ANALYSIS**: Try to find final steady state solution obtain from various ODE solvers. 
 **EVALUATE**: Evaluate the performance of various solvers by calculating relative percentage absolute errors of each solver for different step sizes. 
**CREATE**: Suggest the most suitable solver for the simulation of given distillation column.

Advantages of use of videos are-
Reading through books at times, becomes a tiring task and this is when you can take the help of videos for learning.
It has been proved that visuals are always interesting and engaging than reading through pages after pages. Hence, videos can keep students engaged in the course.
Videos are mostly very demonstration-friendly.
Students who are good visual learners will be having lot of advantages studying from videos. They can store information easily.
The training time is reduced to a great extent using videos.
Limitations of using videos-
Using videos in e-learning courses can be expensive and time-consuming, for you have to spend money and hire people to script, edit and create the video.
Playing video can use a lot of bandwidth and take time to load.
If the video created does not match up the standards of a high quality video, then it can be distracting instead of useful.
There might be problem housing the video in case, you are unable to upload or embed videos directly as allowed by most of the learning management system.

Topic: Parallel architecture and Programming principles
1.	Recall level : First understand what is the parallel computing by knowing the speed of computing machine
2.	Understand level: Why do we need parallel computation by discussing the application that requires high speed computation. For Ex: design of VLSI circuits, weather forecasting, intelligent system etc.
3.	Apply level : Study parallel architecture which falls into two basic categories 
1.	General purpose
2.	Special purpose
4.	Analyze level: Learn important architectural ideas that are designed for general purpose high speed computers like :
1.	Pipeline architecture
2.	Asynchronous architecture
3.	Data flow computers
Special purpose high speed computers like:
4.	Array processor
5.	Systolic array
6.	Neural network
5.	Evaluate level :Students will be able to select the above parallel architecture depending on the commercial architecture like shared and distributed
6.	Create level: The architectural classification aims at characterizing machines so that their architectural contents are reflected in the characterization. Due to the diversity of the ideas implemented by the various machines, a particular characterization may not be adequate in reflecting the

**Videos: Advantages:**
Students can learn anywhere from their mobile devices: laptops, tablets or smartphones.
Learner can learn at their own individual pace and whenever they want.
Allow learner to keep up with the curriculum even if some topic is missed.

**Limitations:**
Using videos in e-learning courses can be expensive and time-consuming.
If the video created does not match up the standards of a high quality video, then it can be distracting instead of useful.

**Animations: Advantages:**
It gains the attention of the viewer.
It helps to carry out certain things that are dangerous to be carried out in the real-life learning such as experiments in Physics and Chemistry.

**Limitations:**
Lot of effort is required to create even a basic animation. Need skill in using the animation software such as Flash.

**Simulations: Advantages:**
Enable the study of behavior of a system without building it. Results are accurate in general, compared to analytical model.

**Limitations:**
It is time consuming and expensive to build a simulation model. It is expensive to conduct simulation.

Classroom A: Advantages 1) Appropriate for complete theoretical subjects. Limitations 1) Most of the students in the class feel boredom.

Classroom B: Advantages 1) Students become agile and can think in all aspects. 2) The class is more demonstrative then just copying texts 3) Students attendance will also be more in experimental classes. 
Limitations 1) Teacher must be fully prepared for the class. 2) Tools for sumulation must be available in classes. 3) Students must be given full authority to use the tools, hardwares etc during the class.

Each of them as own advantages and disadvantages. Appropriate use of technique is needed depending on objective of knowledge transfer and outcome expected. It also depends on the target i.e. type of students. Following is a general thought about it.

Simulations will be more useful for kids as they can learn while playing simulation games.

Animations more useful for explaining concepts at school 8th 9th or 10th level.

Videos more useful at college level and above.

Summarizing:
Classroom A:Suitable for Problem oriented subjects.Students will be able to solve and understand. Active learning.
Limitations: Not suitable where concepts to be explained. 

Class room B:Suitable for explanation and better understanding concepts.Students will be observing and can be included for resource creation activities

Limitations:Not suitable for Problem based subjects where calculations are involved. By seeing calculation, it is not possible for anyone to replicate later. It had to be done then and there

Classroom A:

Advantage: Useful for only theoretical concept.

Limitation: Involvement of student is zero.


Classroom B:

Advantage: Active learning, Interactive

Limitation: Cost of technology used, Extra time required for simulation tools.
Videos are very nice and pleasing to eye. Humans can remember what they have "seen" with their own eyes for a longer time than remembering what they have "read".\nBut one cannot "talk" with a video.
Videos are better way to explain concepts in class and costly as we require setup

Animations are good in the sense that they "speak" with us. But they can't "hear" us. Some times animations can be very useful in driving home some very important concept like traffic rules in minimum effort and time. Not to be used for explaining some basic theory.
Videos, animations and simulations help teaching process to make it effective and active learning occurs
In a developing country like India, simulations is not a tool that can reach the masses. Its biggest advantage is in giving hands on training in least cost.
Correct

**Videos:** **Adv**- 1)Looks Realistic  2)Makes lecture interesting 3) helps in explaining faster
**Disadv**- 1) May not explain things precisely 2)not interactive 3) will not help to assess students

**Animation:** ** **Adv**- 1)helps to explain everything precisely as if any reading to be taken  2)Makes lecture interesting 3) helps in explaining faster

Advantages and Limitations:
Videos
Advantages:1) Makes the topic easy to understand
                   2) Attracts the viewer
                   3) Improved learning takes place rather than just listening to the teacher
                   4) Can be viewed any time 
Limitations:1) Preparation of videos need expensive software
                    2) Requires lot of time to prepare videos
                    3) Not all topics can be converted into videos

Animations
Advantages:1)Topics can be learnt virtually
                   2) Easy to attract students attention
                   3) Interactive as the process/reaction/method/theory can be seen live
Limitations:1) Need technology to create animations
                   2) Each and every topic cannot be animated
                   3) Creation of animation needs skill and time
Simulations
Advantages:1) Excellent way to explain complicated concepts
                    2) Easy to understand
                    3) User can tailor the requirements
                    4) Exercises can be given
Limitations: 1) Technology and time and skill is required
                    2) Doesn't confirm 100% participation of students

**Topic-  Computer Graphics- Scan Conversion and Line Algorithm **

 - Questions- 

**Recall Level-**

1. List the commonly used graphical output primitives.

2. What are operating characteristics for raster refresh system?

3. Write the slope intercept line equation.

**Understand level-**

1.Identifying which pixel position will provide best approximation to a mathematical point P(x,y) where x=4.6 and  y=-9.1  


**Apply Level-**

1.If the line from (2, 2) to (7, 5) is drawn using the DDA Line generation Algo Where starting point is (2,2) identify the pixel coordinate of fourth sample.

**Analyse Level-**

1. Consider a straight line with start point coordinates as(2,7) and end point coordinates as(3,2). Which of following [(a) or (b)] will obtain more sample coordinates to draw line
 
(a) work out the corresponding y coordinate for each unit x coordinate
 
(b) work out the corresponding x coordinate for each unit y coordinate

**Evaluate Level-**

1. Suppose coordinates of start and end points are given and straight line is to be drawn. Which algorithm is more efficient DDA or Bresenham's Algorithm? Why?

**Create Level-**

1.Devise a consistent scheme for implementing the *Polyline* function, for any set of input line endpoints, using line generation algorithm.(Maintining the geometric magnitudes of polygon)

 1. **Identify** the registers used for configuring Timers/counters  ***(L1-Recall)***
 2. **Distinguish** between counting and timing requirements.  ***(L2-Understand)***

       (i)   Whether to configure timer operation or counter operation?
       (ii)  What should be TMOD register value?
