       (iv)  Which Timer is to be used and in which mode?
       (iv)  What should be the initial values to be loaded into the Timer ***(L4-Analyze)***
 5. **Compare** your design with your peer and **justify** your choice of parameters ***(L5-Evaluate)***

***Advantages of Videos***:
Videos  capture realistic visuals which has been found to be effective for learning. Apart from this Video Analysis enables students to better connect graphs to the real world.

***Disdvantages of Videos***
While teaching concepts that requires imagination like voltage, current, atoms or em waves videos are not effective.

***Advantages of Animations*** Animations are very useful when teaching concepts like internal working of 555 timer, illustrating Faraday's laws which requires step by step analysis.

***Disadvantages of Animations*** Not very interactive.

***Advantages of Simulations*** Very interactive. Concepts which require imagination are best understood through simulations.

***Disadvantages of Animations*** Very slow process

**Recall**: How Does a Transformer Work?
**Understand:** Draw the equivalent circuit of single phase transformer showing circuit constants.
**Apply**: Use Emf equation and transformation ratio equation to provide numerical answer to the following: The voltage ratio of a single-phase, 50 Hz transformer is 5,000/500 V at no load. Calculate the number of turns in each winding if the maximum value of the flux in the core is 7.82 mWb.
**Analysis**: Predict how all component voltages and currents in this circuit will be affected as a result of the following faults. Consider each fault independently (i.e. one at a time, no multiple faults)
  1.Transformer T1 primary winding fails open
  2. Transformer T1 primary winding fails shorted
  3. Transformer T1 secondary winding fails open
  4. Load fails shorted
**Evaluate**: In a Transformer, The primary flux is always _________ the secondary ( flux).
  Explain giving numerical example
**Create**: A mechanic goes to school and takes a course in AC electric circuits. Upon learning about step-up and step-down transformers, he makes the remark that “Transformers act like electrical versions of gears, with different ratios.”
What does the mechanic mean by this statement? What exactly is a “gear ratio,” and is this an accurate analogy for a transformer?

1.Recall: Define the 1-Nearest Neighbor classifier
2. Understand: Give your own examples of nearest neighbors for a test sample (20,10).

4. Analyze: Determine the class of the test sample based on a majority vote among its three nearest neighbors.
5. Evaluate: Which of the following is a good way of judging the class of a test sample based on the nearest neighbor classifier a)Nearest Neighbor only b)Majority voting among its k nearest neighbors
6. Create: Devise an algorithm for k-nearest neighbor classifier where the optimum number of neighbors k is determined by the algorithm.

 1. Traditional teaching approach may help students who have rural background and may not have access to modern technology

***Disadvantages of Classroom A***

 1. Students tend to miss out on the huge amount of learning material available in the digital repositories.

 2. Traditional teaching methods (classroom A) are time consuming.

***Advantages of Classroom B***:

 1. Students have access to the huge amount of learning material available in the digital repositories.
 2. Concepts are made clear in less time

***Disadvantages of Classroom B***

1. Students who have rural background, may not have access to modern technology

2.  Interaction with teacher is less and may increase the gap between teachers and students.

**Advantages of Classroom B:**

**Advantages of Videos**

1. Mirror real world.  Replicate real world scenarios better versus text, visual, or just audio.

2. User learns the information easily

3. Help the students to capture the concept easily and more effectively

4. It is flexible i.e stop, rewind, pause, time manipulate, play speed.

5. Videos make it easy to recollect the concepts and helps with effective learning

6. Videos can be accessed through any multimedia device

7. Subtitled Videos boost student interest and improve reading and literacy skills. 

8. Videos provide a sensory experience that allows concepts and ideas to actually become an experience and come to life as students are guided through each activity.

9. Probably higher perceived value.


**Disadvantages of Videos**

1. Not useful for the concepts that are difficult for visualization but this can be overcome by the use of special effects

2. Video playing and screening requires extra hardware, 

3. It is difficult to edit the video

4. Teacher may/may not be active during the lecture hour

5. May be the computer or the projector (LCD) may not work which need time to be fixed and this will lead to delay explaining to some lessons.
 
6. Also, may be the teacher does not know a lot about technology which lead to time spent learning new technologies.

*I think the disadvantages are really challenges.  And once you get going shouldn't be that big of a deal.*

a) BI Definitions and Concepts, Understand BI Component Framework, Mention BI Applications, Know Popular BI Tools,  https://www.khanacademy.org/ \nb) I will be using Think-Pair-Share and Peer Instruction during Visualization.

**Advantages of Animations**

1. Animations convey information more easily

2. Animations help to explain the topic in detail i.e. elaborative manner

3. It is flexible i.e stop, rewind, pause.

4. Teacher may deliver information in fun and catchy manner 

5. Animations will help the students to visualize the complex concepts which cannot be shown by a teacher practically like rocket motion and its speed calculation at a particular time instant.

6. Works best for the first two basic levels of revised bloom’s taxonomy i.e. Recall and Understand

**Disadvantages of Animations**

1. Preparing/making animation is time consuming, 

2. Sometimes without audio the learner may get distracted

3. Animations are not interactive

Advantages:

2. Supports Collaboration Skills:
3. Provides Current Information and Wider Access

**Advantages of Simulations**

1. Keep the user engaged if designed with interactive mode,

2. User enjoys certain simulations then becomes entertaining and exciting,

3. Most relevant to know the matter,

4. Simulations help to realize the practical concepts like firing of bomb from the military tank vehicles indicating the angle and speed of firing,

5. Even though in the preliminary approach simulations are designed to give ideal solutions which are not applicable to real life conditions their real time responses/solutions can be obtained with experience and detailed design approach.

**Disadvantages of Simulations**

1. Designing Simulations is expensive, 

2. It is time consuming

3. It requires much effort with the software knowledge to get the results.

4. To design teacher/provider must know additional software languages

5. Sometimes simulations get treated with game like concepts where the students will play with the simulations.

6. Student’s may not do the calculations but reach the desired value/solution by trial and error

Disadvantages:
    (1) Time allotted.
    (2) Money/Resources.
    (3) Time to product/Learning curve of doing multi-media projects.
    (4) low quality video, then it can be distracting instead of useful.

**Advantages (Animations)**
1. Skill and ability Improvement 
2. Interactivity 
3. Engagement 
4. Flexibility and safety 
5. Motivation 
6. Eliminates frustration 
7. Practicality 
8. Attracting and holding attention 

**Disadvantages:** 
1. Some information of real-life learning will be lost in the animation program.
2. Computer animation programs may function well from a technical point of view, but they are difficult to fit into a curriculum.
3. Not be adapted to take into different student levels into account and consideration within a group or class. To implement this computer animation programs teachers must have certain programming technology and experiences. So it is not easy for every subject teachers.
4. During the experience of interaction with a computer animation or simulation program, the student is frequently asked to solve problems in which creativity is often the decisive factor to success. The fact that is, this creativity is more present in some pupils than in others is not taken into account by the animation or simulation programs. The mutual collaboration and discussion among students while using the software could be a solution for this.
Some technical disadvantages of using animation technology in education:
5. Requires extensive memory and storage space: Since the animation consists of a series of graphic objects and mathematical calculations, it uses more system processing and storage resources than graphics and text.
6. Requires special equipment for a quality presentation: While some good animation can be created using a basic graphics package, producing quality animation requires specialized software and programming and educational knowledge.

**Advantages of Simulations:**
1.Some information of real-life learning will be lost in the animation program.
2. Computer animation programs may function well from a technical point of view, but they are difficult to fit into a curriculum.
3. Not be adapted to take into different student levels into account and consideration within a group or class. To implement this computer animation programs teachers must have certain programming technology and experiences. So it is not easy for every subject teachers.
4. During the experience of interaction with a computer animation or simulation program, the student is frequently asked to solve problems in which creativity is often the decisive factor to success. The fact that is, this creativity is more present in some pupils than in others is not taken into account by the animation or simulation programs. The mutual collaboration and discussion among students while using the software could be a solution for this.

**disadvantages:**
1.Requires extensive memory and storage space: Since the animation consists of a series of graphic objects and mathematical calculations, it uses more system processing and storage resources than graphics and text.
2.Requires special equipment for a quality presentation: While some good animation can be created using a basic graphics package, producing quality animation requires specialized software and programming and educational knowledge.

Topic: Fluid flow operation

Unit: Flow through packed bed 

Target Audience: Pre final year undergraduate Chemical Engineering Students Learning Objectives: (i) Students will be able to understand each term used in  Ergun’s equation (ii) Students will be able to find friction factor and pressure drop with necessary modifications in basic equation for various flow rates through packed bed(iii) Students will be able to do calculation of friction factor of one fluid flowing through a variety of packed material . Question set for Resource Creation Assignment: 

RECALL: Concept of Reynold’s Number, Friction Factor. Write the Ergun’s equation for calculation of friction factor for packed bed.

UNDERSTAND: Try to understand each term of the Ergun’s equation .

APPLY: For a given flowrate condition calculates friction factor.

ANALYSIS: Try to calculate friction factor at different Reynold’s Number.

EVALUATE: Compare friction factor for different flowrate condition to predict its dependency on Reynold’s number.

CREATE: Compare friction factor for variety of packing material with same flowrate. Suggest necessary modification if required in the given equation.

Disadvantage: Such classes need extra infrastructure, facilities and time which sometime not available.

**Topic: Design of Shafts**
**Target Audience : Pre-final year B.Tech. Mechanical Engineering Students**
**Learning Objectives:** Students will be able to compare different types of shafts, should be able to determine shaft diameter based on given loading condition, should be able to compare strength of different types of shafts, should be able to design shafts for given loading, material as per ASME design code
**Recall:**
Define shaft.
**Understand:**
Explain the relationship between torque, shaft diameter and shear stress based on the equation of pure torsion.
**Apply:**
Compute safe diameter of solid circular shaft if it is subjected to torque T Nm and having permission shear strength SMPa.
**Analyze:**
A solid circular shaft is transmitting T Nm torque. It is supported at both ends by means of bearings and carry a central pulley of mass m kg to connect it with electric motor by means of belts.  If the span is L m and permissible strength of material in shear and bending are known, how can be determining safe diameter D of the shaft? Examine stresses induced if the same shaft instead of solid is made hollow with external diameter D (same as solid shaft) and thickness t mm
**Evaluate:**
A hollow circular shaft is subjected to combined bending and torque.  Two different failure theories namely Maximum principal theory and Maximum shear stress theory are used to predict the failure under combined loading on shaft. Two different materials Mild Steel and Cast Iron are available. How can you determine the size of shaft which will be safe? How can you compare solid and hollow shaft made of same material, having same length on the basis of strength and weight?
**Create:**
You are given the yield point tensile strength and ultimate strength of given shaft material. The loading conditions may be static, minor shock or major shock. Shaft is subjected to combined bending moment as well as torque. The shaft should be able to transmit required torque by means of gear mounted on it. Key is used to prevent relative motion between shaft and gear. How can you design the shaft as per ASME code?

Producing: Solidworks for 3D drawing, Autocad,etc

Planning: Sticky Notes and notepad.

Advantages of Type A classroom: 1) The classroom looks very disciplined. There is complete silence except teacher's voice. 2)Students understand how to draw diagrams since they observe teacher drawing it on board. 3)They keep on imagining so imagination power improves. 4)They take notes so writing skill improves

Disadvantages of Type A classroom: 1)Some students feel it ts inactive so they get board.2) Instead of using imagination power for the subject, their mind is occupied with other thoughts 3)There is disparity in the class.Some students with good grasping have advantage and they perform better. 4) Some students who remained absent for prior classes loose interest and cannot concentrate and do not perform well.

Advantage of Type B classroom: 1) Students are very active. 2) They learn many things through peer interaction.3) They gain practical knowledge. 4)They develop many life skills such as team work, leadership, adjustments, decision making etc

Disadvantages of Type B classroom: 1)Teacher should be well prepared 2) He should plan activities well in advance. 3)When group project is given all students  may not contribute equally 4)For some basic topics classroom A type teaching is must.

Title: Tune and evaluate the performance of PI controller for simple first order system
Target audience: B.Tech Chemical Engineering Sem VI students  
Recall: Write PI controller transfer function 
Understand: Arrange the PI controller transfer function in K(N/D) format and see whether it is strictly proper transfer function or not.

Analysis: Analyse the effect of tuning parameters Kc and Tau I on the closed loop system behaviour.
Evaluate: Evaluate the performance of the tuned control parameters in terms of sum of the squared errors between set point and process variable.
Create: Try to develop thump rule to tune PI controller. Compare these results with the already tuned controller performance.

**Questions on topic - Converters (Course - Power Electronics)**

**1. Recall:**
List different types of converters.

**2. Understand**
Explain principle of phase control.

**3. Apply**
A single-phase half-wave SCR circuit feeds power to a resistive load. Draw waveforms for source voltage, load voltage, load current and voltage across the SCR for a given firing angle.

**4. Analyze**
A battery is charged by a single-phase one-pulse thyristor controlled rectifier. The supply is 30 V, 50 Hz and battery emf is constant at 6 V. Find the resistance to be inserted in series with the battery to limit the charging current to 4 A on the assumption that SCR is triggered continuously. Take a voltage drop of 1 V across the SCR. 

**5. Evaluate**
A single-phase one-pulse SCR controlled converter feeds an RL load with a freewheeling diode across the load, discuss how freewheeling diode comes into play when supply voltage is passing through zero and becoming negative. 
Derive expressions for the load current as a function of time during conduction as well as freewheeling periods. 

**6. Create**
Design a half wave controlled rectifier circuit using following information - 
Input - single-phase transformer with secondary voltage of 230 V, 50 Hz, Load R = 10 ohm, Firing angle delay of 60°.

Topic: Mass transfer 

Unit: Design of tray tower for fractional distillation.

Target Audience: Pre Final year Chemical Engineering Students

Learning objectives: (1) Students will be able to understand the effect of different parameters used in design of column (2) Students can design the tray tower based on various parameters such as temperature, pressure, reflux ratio, concentration and liquid/gas ratio. (3)Students can calculate the height of the tower and number of trays installed in tower using McCabe–Thiele method. (4)Students will be able to choose best combination of design parameters for given condition.

Question set for Resource Creation Assignment:  
 
Recall: Develop mass balance equations based on the given condition for the column.
Understand: Can you develop component (solute) balance equations based on the given concentration of solute in different streams?

Apply: For a given condition of temperature, pressure, concentration, reflux ratio and liquid/gas ratio, calculate the number of trays to be installed in a tower using McCabe–Thiele method.

Analysis: If the value of one of the variable is changed, what will be the effect on design of tower in terms of the height, diameter and number of trays?
Evaluate: For a given condition of feed to be introduced, one has to develop mass balance and component balance equations. Based on the amount of products to be obtained with percentage separation of solute and reflux ratio, calculate the numbers of trays required in tower.

Create: Design and calculate a numbers of tray required in  a tray tower with consideration of two different reflux ratio and percentage separation of solute. For this check the condition of the feed and feed location. Compare the results obtained for two reflux ratio and suggest optimum value of reflux ratio for desired separation.

**Questions based on Bloom’s Taxonomy:**

**Course**: Satellite Communication

**Topic**: Geostationary Satellite

**Recall**: Define the term ‘Geostationary Satellite’.

**Understand**: Illustrate the conditions that are necessary to be satisfied by a satellite orbit to be perfectly Geostationary.

**Apply**: Based on the fact that the earth rotates once per sidereal day of 23 h 56 min 4.09 sec, compute the height at which the satellite is to be launched so that it is in the geostationary orbit.

**Analyze**: Diagnose the effects of following situations on the geostationarity of the orbit of the satellite:
i.	The orbit is elliptical instead of being circular.
ii.	The orbit has inclination with respect to equatorial plane instead of being in the plane of the equator.

**Evaluate**: Assess the performance effects when a satellite system deviates from a perfect geostationary orbit to a partial geostationary orbit (quasi-geo orbit).

**Create**: Devise the remedial action-plan to be taken by a ground station controller and the receiving earth station when the satellite orbit deviates from geotationarity.

**Summarising**

> 1.GreatSummary           
         http://www.greatsummary.com/index.htm                                                                                      
Great Summary is a useful website which allows you to summarize articles right from your browsers. There are two options to choose from: Document Summarization or GreatSummary Subscriptions.he latter creates a news feed for a webpage to track any changes made in it. For e.g: making one for some Wikipedia page to know if some new information was added or altered.
The first option allows you to put any web-page link in the URL box, and choose in how many lines you need the summary. Click “Summarize” and you will get a brief paragraph on the article, with only the main points
      

> 2.Smmry               
http://smmry.com/              
Free Summarizer allows you to copy a passage of text and paste it in the text box. You can then choose the number of sentences in which the summary should be made, and input your email to which the summary will be emailed.You can also choose the number of sentence for the summary. The less the sentences, the smaller the summary.

**Classifying**           

> 1.Autonomy Categorizer       
Creates concept maps and topic clusters without human intervention by using Bayesian probability and pattern-recognition. Users have complained that the system can be slow and the automation difficult to understand.     
> 2.EasyAsk    
Works with database structures to generate categories, and puts items from multiple search engines into topical categories.

TPS and PI can be used for formative assessment as this can help to improve the students involvement and make them to know their level of understanding.For summative assessment it is not a good method.\n\nFormative method is used during the course while summative assessment is used at the end of the course to grade students individually.

Advantages: Classroom A: Improves listening and writing skills, Technology independent. Classroom B: interactive, develops collaborative learning and team work.\n\nDisadvantages: Classroom A: Non-interactive,complete learning may not happen, no immediate feed back. Classroom B: Time (consuming)management, Technology dependent

**TubeChop**  
http://www.tubechop.com/
gives you the ability to clip a section from any YouTube video and share it. This could be useful if there is a section of long YouTube video that you want to share with your students. One such instance could be if you want to show students studying public speaking a section of commencement address as a model.

**Splicd**         
http://www.splicd.com/
is a service that lets users select and share a segment of a YouTube video. Splicd is a simple and easy service to use. To use Splicd all you have to do is select a video from YouTube, copy the video's url into Splicd, then enter the start and end times of the video segment you wish to watch. This service will be particularly useful for those times that you want to share only a part of a long video.

These technology tools use the power of social media to help students learn and teachers connect.
 1. Edmodo: Teachers and students can take advantage of this great tech tool, as it offers a Facebook-like environment where classes can connect online.
 2. Grockit: Get your students connected with each other in study sessions that take place on this great social site.
 3. EduBlogs: EduBlogs offers a safe and secure place to set up blogs for yourself or your classroom.
 4. Skype: Skype can be a great tool for keeping in touch with other educators or even attending meetings online. Even cooler, it can help teachers to connect with other classrooms, even those in other countries.
 5. Wikispaces: Share lessons, media, and other materials online with your students, or let them collaborate to build their own educational wiki on Wikispaces.
 6. Pinterest: You can pin just about any image you find interesting on this site, but many teachers are using it as a place to collect great lesson plans, projects, and inspirational materials.
 7. Schoology: Through this social site, teachers can manage lessons, engage students, share content, and connect with other educators.
 8. Quora: While Quora is used for a wide range of purposes, it can be a great tool for educators. It can be used to connect with other professionals or to engage students in discussion after class.
 9. Ning: Ning allows anyone to create a personalized social network, which can be great for both teachers and students alike.
 10. OpenStudy:Encourage your students to work together to learn class material by using a social study site like OpenStudy.
 11. ePals: One of the coolest benefits of the Web is being able to connect with anyone, anywhere. ePals does just that, but focuses on students, helping them to learn languages and understand cultures different from their own.
 12. Khan Academy: Many teachers use this excellent collection of math, science, and finance lectures and quizzes to supplement their classroom materials.
 13. MangaHigh: MangaHigh offers teachers a wealth of resources for game-based learning in mathematics.
 14. FunBrain: If you’re looking for a great collection of educational games, look no further than FunBrain. On it, teachers can take advantage of fun tools for math and reading.
 15. Educreations: Educreations is an amazing online tool for the iPad that lets teachers (or students) create videos that teach a given topic. Perfect for studying or getting students to show off their knowledge.
 16. Animoto: Animoto makes it simple to create video-based lessons or presentations for the classroom and to share them with students or anyone else.
 17. Socrative: Available for computers, mobile devices, and tablets, this student response system engages students through games and exercises on any device they have on hand. Even better, teachers can easily assess student progress and track grades.
 18. Knewton: Adaptive learning has been a hot topic in recent months, and with Knewton it’s something that any teacher can access and use. The site personalizes online learning content for each student according to his or her needs.
 19. Kerpoof: On Kerpoof, students can get creative with their learning with games, interactive activities, drawing tools, and more that are both fun and educational.
 20. StudySync: With a digital library, weekly writing practice, online writing and peer reviews, Common Core assignments, and multimedia lessons available, this site is a fully-featured tool for teaching and learning that can be a big help in the classroom.
 21. CarrotSticks: On this site, teachers can take advantage of a wide range of math learning games, giving students practice while they have fun.
 22. Teachers Pay Teachers: Have great lessons to share? Looking for something to add to your classes? On this site you can do both, selling your own class materials and buying high-quality resources from other teachers.
 23. Planboard: Make sure your lessons are organized and that your day runs smoothly with the help of this amazing online tool designed just for teachers.
 24. Timetoast: Timetoast is a pretty cool for student projects, allowing them to build sleek, interactive timelines in minutes.
 25. Capzles: There are so many different ways that Capzles can be used in the classroom, there’s bound to be an application that fits your needs. What does it do? Capzles makes it simple to gather media like photos, videos, documents, and even blog posts into one place, making it perfect for teaching, learning, or online projects.
 26. Prezi: Want to build presentations that will wow your students? Make use of this online tool that makes it simple to do all kinds of cool things with your lessons, even allowing collaboration between teachers.
 27. Wordle: Create stunning word clouds using Wordle, a great complement to language lessons of any kind.
 28. QR Codes: QR codes (or quick response codes) are showing up with greater frequency in education. If you’d like to get in on the trend, you’ll need a tool to create and manage the codes like Delivr and one to read codes, like any of those listed on this site.
 29. Quizlet: Quizlet makes it easy for teachers to create study tools for students, especially flashcards that can make memorizing important information a snap.
 30. MasteryConnect: How are your students performing with regard to state and common core standards? MasterConnect makes it simple to track and analyze both, as well as other elements of student performance.
 31. Google Docs: Through Google Docs, teachers can create and share documents, presentations, or spreadsheets with students and colleagues as well as give feedback on student-created projects.
 32. YouTube: Not all schools allow YouTube, but they are missing out as the site contains a wealth of great learning materials for the classroom. There’s even a special education-focused channel just for teachers and students.
 33. TED-Ed: TED isn’t just a great place to find inspiration anymore, the site also contains numerous videos that are organized by subject and can help you to teach everything from how pain relievers work to Shakespearean insults.
 34. Glogster:Glogster is a social site that lets users mash up music, photos, videos, and pretty much anything else you’d like. It’s a great way to create learning materials and a handy tool for creative student projects.
 35. Creaza: Want to bring your student projects into the 21st century? Creaza can make that possible, offering tools to brainstorm, create cartoons, and edit audio and video.
 36. Mentor Mob: On Mentor Mob, you or your students can create a learning playlist, which is essentially a collection of high-quality materials that can be used to study a specific concept.
 37. Evernote: Capture great ideas, photos, recordings, or just about anything else on your Evernote account, access it anywhere, and keep it organized. A must-have tool for lesson planning.
 38. Twitter: There are so many ways Twitter can be used in education. Teachers can connect with other educators, take part in chats, share their ideas, or even use it in the classroom to reach out to students.
 39. Google Education: Google offers a number of great edtech resources for teachers, including email and collaborative apps, videos, lesson plan search, professional development, and even educational grants.
 40. Dropbox: Easily store, share, and access any kind of data from anywhere with the easy-to-use and free Dropbox service.
 41. Diigo: Diigo lets you treat the web like paper-based reading material, making it simple to highlight, bookmark, take notes, or even add sticky notes.
 42. Apple iPad: One of the most widely used, though expensive, tech tools being used in today’s classroom is the Apple iPad. With a host of educational apps being developed for the device, it’s become a favorite of teachers and students alike across the nation.
 43. Aviary: Aviary is a suite of tools that make it easy to edit images, effects, swatches, music, and audio or to create and modify screen captures.
 44. Jing: If you’re teaching kids about tech or just about anything else, a great screenshot program is essential. Jing is one great option that allows teachers to take screenshots as images, record up to five minutes or videos then edit and share the results.
 45. Popplet: You and your students can use Popplet to brainstorm ideas, create mindmaps, share, and collaborate.
 46. Google Earth: From geography projects to learning about geological processes, Google Earth can be an amazing and fast way to show students anywhere in the world.
 47. DonorsChoose: Need funding for a classroom project? You can get it through this site that hooks up needy teachers with willing donors.
 48. SlideShare: With SlideShare, you can upload your presentations, documents, and videos and share them with students and colleagues. Even better, you can take advantage of materials that other have uploaded as well.
 49. LiveBinders: Like a real-life three ring binder, this tech tool allows you to collect and organize resources. Much better than a binder, however, the site also comes with tools to connect and collaborate and a virtual whiteboard.
 50. AudioBoo: Through this tool, you can record and share audio for your students or anyone else.

Videos
Advantages: They capture realistic visuals which and be used to make the concepts clear.
Disadvantages: Certain concepts like atoms, molecules etc. which are not visible to the naked eye cant be explained effectively. Also there are certain locations like furnace, volcanoes, high altitudes etc. where cameras cant reach.

Animations
Advantages: Visuals related to concepts like atoms, molecules which are not visible to the naked eye can be effectively shown.
Disadvantages: They are artificial. The process of designing may be time consuming.

Simulations
Advantages: They provide control for changing parameters.
Disadvantages: The process of designing may be time consuming.

Structuring: AutoCAD and Solidworks software.

Deconstructing: Matlab and Pspice software.

Mashing: MagNet and other FEM software.

**Videos**:
Advantages: It assures more engagement of the students and will be more appealing for the basic concepts/ procedure. Concept can be demonstrated with real life examples
Disadvantages: No technical details or insight of the concept/ system.

**Animations**: Advantages: It can capture different instants of process/ motion/ system. Imaginary concepts can also be taught.   Disadvantages: Not interactive in terms of parameter variations.

**Simulation**:
Advantages: Enhances teaching learning process with more technicality. Thought process is initiated to draw some conclusion.   Disadvantages: Making of simulated model may be a time consuming. Also basic awareness about the process or the fact is required.

Topics  (a) Rate of Reaction (b)Effect of Concentration and Temperature on rate of reaction  (d) Equilibrium condition for reaction
Description 	
1.	Why a reaction happen by colliding atoms and molecules? 
2.	 Design experiments with different reactions, concentrations, and temperatures. 
3.	When are reactions reversible? What affects the rate of a reaction?
Sample Learning Goals 
•	Explain why and how a pinball shooter can be used to help understand ideas about reactions.
•	Describe on a microscopic level what contributes to a successful reaction (with illustrations).
•	Describe how the reaction coordinate can be used to predict whether a reaction will proceed or slow.
•	Use the potential energy diagram to determine: The activation energy for the forward and reverse reactions; The difference in energy between reactants and products; The relative potential energies of the molecules at different positions on a reaction coordinate.
•	Draw a potential energy diagram from the energies of reactants and products and activation energy.
•	Sketch how the number of reactants and products will change as a reaction proceeds.
•	Explain how they know that a system has reached equilibrium from a graph of number of reactants and products versus time.
•	Predict how raising or lowering the temperature will affect a system in the equilibrium position.
•	Describe the relative sizes of the forward and reverse rates at equilibrium.
•	Explain what effects whether the equilibrium position favors the products or the reactants.
•	Predict how addition of a reactant or product will affect the forward and reverse reaction rates, and once this new system reaches equilibrium how the reactant and product concentrations will compare to the original system at equilibrium.
•	Compare graphs of concentration vs. time to determine which represents the fastest or slowest rate.
URL: http://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/reactions-and-rates

How do greenhouse gases affect the climate? Explore the atmosphere during the ice age and today. What happens when you add clouds? •	Explain why greenhouse gases affect temperature

**Subject:** Theory of Machines  
**Topic:** Friction in pivot and collar bearings & clutches

**Target Audience**: Students of Second year mechanical engineering.

**1.	Recall level questions:**  

i.	State different types of pivot and collar bearings.

ii.	State Uniform pressure and uniform wear theory.

iii.	Identify different clutches.

iv.	State formulae for torque required to overcome the friction in each case of bearing.

**2.	Understand level questions:**  

i.	Draw diagrams for each type of bearing and clutch and explain working of each type.

ii.	Describe function of each component in single plate/ multi plate clutch.

**3.	Apply level questions:**

i.	Calculate torque transmitting capacity of clutch with given input using elementary equations.

ii.	Calculate torque required to overcome friction in case of bearing with given input using elementary equations.

**4.	Analyze level questions:**

i.	Which theory should be adopted for designing clutch and bearing for safe working condition, justify your answer.

ii.	Analyze the effect of use of uniform pressure theory and wear theory on design of bearing and clutches.

**5.	Evaluate level questions:**

i.	Select the proper clutch for given application (single plate clutch or multi plate clutch), when input parameters like speed, torque, space limitations are provided. Justify your answers with numerical data. 

**6.	Create level question:**

i.	Design a clutch for transmission system of a machine/ an automobile.

ii.	Optimize the clutch dimensions for reducing the weight and cost.

Videos:
 Advantages: They capture realistic visuals which are used to make the concepts very clear. Disadvantages: Certain concepts like atoms, molecules etc. which are not visible to the naked eye, can't be explained effectively but model visualization can be shown here also.

**Topic:** Resistance of a conductor 

**URL:** http://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/resistance-in-a-wire/latest/resistance-in-a-wire_en.html 

**Learning objective:** The student will be able to understand the dependency of 'resistance' of a conductor on parameters like 'resistivity (rho)', 'length (L)' and 'area (A)'.

**Strategy:**
1. Pause the simulation and pose the TPS question : "What is the effect of parameters like 'resistivity (rho)', 'length (L)' and 'area (A)' on Resistence of conductor."

2. Ask the students to share answers.

3.Confirm the correct answer by running the simulation once again.

ADVANTAGES OF CLASSROOM A 1.Listening skills of student will be improved 2.Knowledge transfer will be good when time and resources available are limited DISADVANTAGES OF CLASSROOM A 1.Student involvement is passive 2.Technology use is very minimal ADVANTAGES OF CLASSROOM B 1.Technology can be used in the trans-formative way 2. **Classroom A**:

**Advantage**: 

Not Useful for proper learning. Monotonous routine for both teachers and students.

**Limitation**: 

Direct Involvement of students is very less. Less interaction between teacher and students.

**Classroom B**:

**Advantage**: 

Active participation of students and teacher is possible.students can learn more and can develop ideas of their own.Good for higher level learning process.

**Limitation**: 

Teacher has to do lot of home work and should prepare a subject in a better way.

               pilot is trained in simulator before flying, driving skills can be
               learned
             - Cost effective technique to impart training.
Disadvantages :   -Simulations are made under certain assumptions
                  -It may not give real experience
                  - Initial training is required to work in simulations
                  - Good skills are required for making good simulations

Learning objective : Students should be able to calculate the density for cubic systems.


Recall Level: Memorize the formula for the density of cubic unit cell.

Understand level:Discuss the density for Simple and body centered cube. 

Apply level: Copper has FCC structure and atomic radius is 1.3 A. Determine its density (Given : Molecular wt = 63.54, NA=6.023 X 10^26/kgmol.

Analyze Level: Sodium crystallizes in a cubic lattice. The edge of unit cell is 3.4 A. The density of unit cell is 963 kg/m3 and atomic wt is 23. How many atoms are contained in one unit cell? (NA=6.023 X 10^26/kgmol.)

Evaluate Level:The edge of Na unit cell is 4.3 A?. Its  density and molecular weight are 963 kg/m3 and 23 respectively. Calculate the no. of atoms per unit cell. What type of cubic unit cell does sodium form. (NA=6.02 X 10^26/kgmol).

Create Level: Derive the formula for density of unit cell for tetragonal unit cell.

Mechanical Vibration

Question 1) Remember-Define the resonance in vibration for mechanical system.

2)Understand-Explain the types of vibrations.

3)Apply-Derive an equation for undamped single degree of freedom system.

Topic: Geostationary Satellite
Type of Knowledge: Concept
URL of the Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hcm7oQwpZfg

3-2-1 strategy 
1. Three
After the lesson, have each student record three things he or she learned from the lesson.

2. Two
Next, have students record two things that they found interesting and that they’d like to learn more about.

3. One
Then, have students record one question they still have about the material.


4. Review
Finally, the most important step is to review the students’ responses. You can use this information to help develop future lessons and determine if some of the material needs to be taught again.

**VIDEOS**

**Advantages:** Realistic, leads to better understanding, Engaging, learning videos give the experience to the students. Can be repeated as many no. of times, can be shown in more than one place at a time.
(picture is worth thousand words, but a video is worth million of words.)

**Limitations:** All concepts cannot be taught by videos, one way (Not interactive), there may be problem of time management due to duration of video, dependency on video/audio equipment and quality of video, Teacher must be well trained to use the equipment.

**ANIMATIONS**

**Advantages:** Easy learning, more flexible, can be made interactive, more engaging than videos, complex phenomenon can be easily explained.

**Limitations:** Cannot depict actual life events exactly(some information may be lost), requirement of software and knowledge for making the animations. Some trainning may be also required for teachers.


**SIMULATIONS**

**Advantages:** Highly interactive, dangerous situations like driving and flight training can be handled  safely, can be used to predict the outcomes of certain events.(As shown in LeD video3), Can be used to achive the higher order learning objectives Create and Evaluate.


**Limitations:** High dependence on technology, students may think it as a game and so seriousness in learning may not come.

Course: Mechanics of Materials 
TOPIC: Deflection of beams by Macaulay's Method

Level 1 (Recall) question-1
Write the fundamental 2nd order differential equation used to find deflection of simple beams.

Level 2 (Understand) question-2 
Write a full Macaulay equation to get deflection at any point located at "x" along the span 
of beam for two point loads P1 and P2 located at distance x1 and x2 from left support of a simply supported beam.Consider Span "l". How many subterms appear on R.H.S. of equation?


Level 3 (Apply) question-3
 Solve for deflection at center of beam in question 2 above by taking following numerical values P1=10KN, P2=20KN, x1=2m,x2=4m,l=6m, Material of beam steel and its crossection is rectangle with width 20mm and depth 200mm. Where does the maximum deflection occures and how much?

Level 4 (Analyse) question-4  
   If in question-3 above the load P2 is replaced by 20KN.m  anticlockwise moment, what will be change in the deflection at centre? Does the deflected shape changes?

Level 5 (Evaluate) question-5
By looking into the procedure suggested by Macaulay, bring out advantages,limitations, deficiencies of this method in detail with examples.

Level 6 (Create) question-6
Design a I section steel beam of specification Indian standard I section, if it is to be used as girder of asimple footbridge of span 12m. Take maximum loads P1 and P2 to be 150KN each with x1=3m and x2=7m from left support. The limit on maximum deflection is span/225

Technology has drastically changed the ways of learning as well as teaching. There are many advantages of using videos, animation and simulation in teaching as described below:
1) They engage the attention of learners and sustain the attention for a long time.
2) They make the concepts clear.
3) They help learners understand the processes.
4) They help teachers explain concepts in less time and so on.
The disadvantages are as described below:
1) The teacher may not always be able to make changes in them.
2) They can not be modified easily.
3) They need availability of required resources for display.

Here I have enclosed a set questions for 6 levels of Taxonomy which is used in Foundation Engineering. Please Review it, and provide me feedback. Thanks.

**Level 1 - Recall Level Question**
Write the ultimate bearing capacity equation for the general shear failure of soil in Terzaghi’s analysis for a square footing

**Level 2 - Understand level Question**
Is the Water table in the soil profile affects bearing capacity of the soil? If it is yes, how?

**Level 3 - Apply level Question**
Compute the safe bearing capacity of a square footing 1.5 m x 1.5 m located at a depth of 1 m below the ground level in a soil of average density 20 kN/m3 . ? = 20°, Nc = 17.7, Nq = 7.4 and N? = 5. Assume a suitable factor of safety and that the water table is very deep.

**Level 4 - Analyze level question**
A Strip footing of width 3m is founded at a depth of 2m below the ground surface in a (c-?) soil having a cohesion c = 30 kN/m2 and angle of shearing resistance ? = 35o . The moist weight of soil above the water table is 17.25 kN/m2 . For ? = 35o , Nc = 57.8, Nq = 41.4 and N? = 42.4 For ? = 25o , Nc = 25.1, Nq = 12.7 and N? = 9.7 . 
Assume ?sat = 18.5 kN/m3 , ? (above WT) = 17.5 kN/m3 , Factor of Safety = 3
If the water table occupies any of the positions 
(i)	1.25 m below Ground Level 
(ii)	 1.25 m below the base level of the foundation, What will be the net safe bearing pressure?
 
**Level 5 - Evaluate level Question**
A site is under investigation for the construction of a new Hospital. In the investigation it is found that top 3m of the soil is of Medium sand compact and dry. Next 4m is of black cotton soil. Then again for 2m the soil is of medium sand. Then rock strata starts. What type of foundation can be suggested for this site for the construction of a 4 storey hospital building?

**Level 6 - Create level Question**
Design a shallow foundation to support column load 800kN, base of footing is expected at 3ft below the ground level, having a cohesion c = 30 kN/m2 and angle of shearing resistance ? = 35deg. The moist weight of soil above the water table is 17.25 kN/m2 . For ? = 35deg, Nc = 57.8, Nq = 41.4 and N? = 42.4

1. Recall: Define the functionality of EXOR Gate?
Ans: Functionality of EXOR Gate is the output is one when both the inputs are different along with truth table and symbol.
2. Understand: Explain the properties of EXOR Gate (commutative, associative)
Ans:
Commutative: (A EXOR B) = (B EXOR A) along with truth table and symbol.
Associative: ((A EXOR B) EXOR C) = (A EXOR (B EXOR C)) = (B EXOR (C EXOR A)) along with truth table and symbol.
3. Apply: Relate the EVEN and ODD Function using EXOR Gate.
Ans: 
1. Odd Function:In general, an exclusive-OR function of n-variables is an odd function which has a value of 1 IFF the number of 1’s in the input combination is odd, otherwise it has a value of 0. Since XOR gates are only designed with 2 inputs, the 3-input XOR function is
implemented by means of two 2-input XOR gates,along with truth table and symbol. 
2. Even Function: The complement of an odd function is an even function. The even function is equal to 1 when the number of 1’s in the input combination is even.
The complement of an odd function (an even function) is obtained by replacing the
output gate with an exclusive-NOR gate, along with truth table and symbol.
4. Analyze:Differentiate between Even and Odd Function using the circuits and truth table.
5. Evaluate: EXOR Functions are very useful in systems using parity bits for error detection. A parity bit is extra bit which is used for purpose of detecting errors during transmission of binary information i.e. it is included with binary message.Can you conclude how the parity bit can either be even or odd. 
6. Create: Can you design a circuit for the requirements are as under, in a room there are three doors, each door has a bulb connected to it along with a bidirectional connected at each door. Whenever a door gets open then bulb gets ON and whenever a door gets close the bulb gets OFF.

We do invest significant time and resources in developing our teaching capability based on International best practice models. We do participate in a variety workshop, seminars and conferences and some of us have pursued specialist teaching qualifications. 
All of these activities were aimed at delivering on our Strategic Plan commitments as represented in goals.
We try to make ourselves available for students. We have our knowledge accessible to students, we also takes care to produce an independent learner. To achieve these goals it is imperative that students actively engage with the curriculum and the teaching process and that they develop a motivation and discipline to learn in both group and individual settings. 
This strategy was developed to facilitate achievement of these goals. This strategy represents our approach to delivering the best possible learning experience for students that will promote independent learning and academic achievement. In implementing the strategy departments and lecturers will strive to ensure that students are exposed to modern, effective teaching models that engage students.
Let us summarize the discussion as follows: 
OBJECTIVES: articulate the knowledge and skills we want students to acquire by the end of the course 
ASSESSMENTS: allow the instructor to check the degree to which the students are meeting the learning objectives 
INSTRUCTIONAL STRATEGIES are chosen to foster student learning towards meeting the objectives. When these components are not aligned, students might rightfully complain that the test did not have anything to do with what was covered in class, or instructors might feel that even though students are earning a passing grade, they haven’t really mastered the material at the desired level.

Even though in actuality there are many processes running at once, the OS gives each process the illusion that it is running alone.
•	Virtual time: The time used by just this processes. Virtual time progresses at a rate independent of other processes. Actually, this is false, the virtual time is typically incremented a little during systems calls used for process switching; so if there are more other processors more ``overhead'' virtual time occurs.
•	Virtual memory: The memory as viewed by the process. Each process typically believes it has a contiguous chunk of memory starting at location zero. Of course this can't be true of all processes (or they would be using the same memory) and in modern systems it is actually true of no processes (the memory assigned is not contiguous and does not include location zero).
Virtual time and virtual memory are examples of abstractions provided by the operating system to the user processes so that the latter ``sees'' a more pleasant virtual machine than actually exists.

5.Evaluate:Can we use a square law modulator circuit(used for modulation) for demodulation of a standard AM (DSBFC) wave? Elaborate your claim with mathematical derivation and block diagram.

6.Create: Design an AM modulator circuit using a nonlinear device with following V-I characteristics i=av+bv^3. Explain all the blocks required with the help of a diagram and mathematical expressions.

for odd functions ,if the number of 1's in the input combination is odd,the output will be 0 and vice versa. Multilevel inputs can be given by Combinations of Two inputs EXNOR.

Define modulation index of an AM wave?

When does over-modulation take place and what is its effect?

An AM transmitter radiates 9kW of power when the carrier is unmodulated and 10.125kW when the carrier is sinusoidally modulated. Find the modulation index for the given system.

The antenna current at AM transmitter is 8 A if only the carrier is sent, but it increases to 8.93 A if the carrier is modulated by a single sinusoidal wave. Determine percent modulation and also find the antenna current if the percent of modulation changes to 80%.

An AM transmitter signal is modulated to a depth of 40% and antenna current of 11 A. This current increases to 12 A as a result of simultaneous modulation by another audio sine wave. What is the modulation depth of this second wave?

**Create –** 
For a non-sinusoidal modulating signal x(t) derive the expression for an AM wave.

URL : https://www.tools4noobs.com/summarize/
To paraphrase means to restate someone else’s ideas in your own language at roughly the same level of detail. To summarize means to reduce the most essential points of someone else’s work into a shorter form. Along with quotation, paraphrase and summary provide the main tools for integrating your sources into your papers. When choosing which to use, consider first your discipline and the type of writing in which you are engaged. For example, literature reviews in science reports rely almost exclusively on summary. Argumentative essays, by contrast, rely on all three tools.

Paraphrase and summary are indispensable in argumentative papers because they allow you to include other people’s ideas without cluttering up your paragraphs with quotations. These techniques help you take greater control of your essay. Consider using either tool when an idea from one of your sources is important to your essay but the wording is not. Space limitations may guide you in your choice. But above all, think about how much of the detail from your source is relevant to your argument. If your reader needs to know only the bare bones, then summarize.

Though paraphrase and summary are often preferable to quotation, do not rely too heavily on them, either. Your ideas are what matter most. Allow yourself the space to develop those ideas.

URL : http://www.fefana.org/ClassTool/
 Segmentation and classification tools provide an approach to extracting features from imagery based on objects. These objects are created via an image segmentation process where pixels in close proximity and having similar spectral characteristics are grouped together into a segment. Segments exhibiting certain shapes, spectral, and spatial characteristics can be further grouped into objects. The objects can then be grouped into classes that represent real-world features on the ground. Image classification can also be performed on pixel imagery, for example, traditional unsegmented imagery.

The object-oriented feature extraction process is a workflow supported by tools covering three main functional areas; image segmentation, deriving analytical information about the segments, and classification. Data output from one tool is the input to subsequent tools, where the goal is to produce a meaningful object-oriented feature class map. The object-oriented process is similar to a traditional image, pixel-based classification process, utilizing supervised and unsupervised classification techniques. Instead of classifying pixels the process classifies segments, which can be thought of as super pixels. Each segment, or super pixel, is represented by a set of attributes that are used by the classifier tools to produce the classified image.

URL : http://www.digitaltutors.com/subject/2d-animation-tutorials
How Animated Movies Are Made

What is animation? Animation is the art of brining something to life. How it's brought to life can be done any number of different ways. It can be drawn, like Mike Surrey here to the right. You can make a model of it and move it, like in "The Nightmare Before Christmas." You can put it on a computer, like Toy Story. Or you can cut out bits of paper and move the paper, like (yech) South Park (the original one anyways). You can even move whole people around, photographing them one frame at a time, so they can move without walking. All of these are different forms of animation.

How it all gets started - Pre-Production

Animated movies start much the same way normal movies do. Someone has an idea, that idea gets accepted by a bunch of studio heads, and the studio starts working on it. Ron Clements talks about how "Aladdin" got started in Aladdin: the making of an animated film:

    "When we finished Mermaid, we didn't know what we were going to do next. Jeffrey [Katzenburg] offered us three projects. One was Swan Lake. Another was King of the Jungle [which later became The Lion King]. The third was Aladdin. Swan Lake seemed too much like Mermaid, which we had just finished, so it was between King of the Jungle and Aladdin. Aladdin seemed like the most fun."

So much for inspiration. The directors then go on to write out their version of story. The story is discussed and refined (Jasmin's age, for example, was switched from "15" to "indeterminate" when Jeffery Katzenburg decided that they should send out the message that it was all right to get married at age 15!). At the same time, research crews are sent out to the "location" of the film, be it Africa for The Lion King or China for Mulan, so that they'll have something to boast about on the ABC Special just before the film comes out. But seriously, the artists take pictures, make sketches and, well, enjoy themselves (this is the good part of making a movie!) and do play an important role in developing the look and feel of the film. Back at the studio, artists are making inspirational sketches (see pictures on this page) suggesting mood, setting, characters and plot for the movie. Some of these inspirational sketches may also be adapted to become story sketches later in production.

Jobs in Pre-production:

    Inspirational artist
    Any other artist at a studio can participate in this stage

Production and Story- The real work begins

Many films never make it past the pre-production stage. Films such as "Hiawatha" and "Chanticlere" are now fading memories in the minds of those who conceived them; they were never made into movies. However, those lucky movies that are given the go-ahead by management now go into production. Production in animation is not like production in live-action, where you just go out, shoot the picture and come home. Well, okay, it is, sort of, but it takes a lot longer. Jurassic Park was in production for about 80 or so days; the bulk of the time was done in pre and post production (the puppet dinosaurs were created in pre and the computer ones were added in post, if you must know). An animated film, however, will be in full production much longer; the shortest was The Great Mouse Detective, which took a year.

So, what's the first stage of production? The storyboards are the first things to be created. A storyboard is basically a giant bristol board, on which you can tack story sketches, which are (surprise!) sketches which illustrate the story. What these boards do is show roughly how every scene in the movie will look. It looks nothing so much like a giant comic strip, with the exception that the dialogue, instead of being included in the drawing, is separated out and put below. (Note: the movie scripts are either written at the same time or slightly before the storyboards. However, the two undergo constant revisions at the same time, so it is fair to say they go together.) The dialogue is also recorded at this time - it too will often undergo revisions. The reason the storyboards are pinned up, in case you haven't guessed, is so that they can be easily torn down, as they often are when the story changes. An entire version of Be Our Guest in "Beauty and the Beast" was scrapped when the story was not working; so were all the story sketches on that part of the boards.

**Advantages of videos, animation and simulation:**
1.Videos are mostly demonstration friendly. Training time is reduced.
2. Animation gains attention of the viewer
3. Simulation helps in theory with practice of teaching.

**Limitations of using Videos, animation and simulation in teaching:**
1. While using videos in the class room, there can be some technical difficulties such as softwares, hardwares or networks.
2. Animation takes alot of effort to create even a basic animation.
3. Simulation has no emphasis is given on teaching skills or content taught. Only the social behaviour is considered.

Here I have enclosed a set questions for 6 levels of Taxonomy which is used in Foundation Engineering. Please Review it, and provide me feedback. Thanks.
Level 1 - Recall Level Question Write the ultimate bearing capacity equation for the general shear failure of soil in Terzaghi’s analysis for a square footing

Level 2 - Understand level Question Is the Water table in the soil profile affects bearing capacity of the soil? If it is yes, how?

Level 3 - Apply level Question Compute the safe bearing capacity of a square footing 1.5 m x 1.5 m located at a depth of 1 m below the ground level in a soil of average density 20 kN/m3 . ? = 20°, Nc = 17.7, Nq = 7.4 and N? = 5. Assume a suitable factor of safety and that the water table is very deep.

Level 4 - Analyze level question A Strip footing of width 3m is founded at a depth of 2m below the ground surface in a (c-?) soil having a cohesion c = 30 kN/m2 and angle of shearing resistance ? = 35o . The moist weight of soil above the water table is 17.25 kN/m2 . For ? = 35o , Nc = 57.8, Nq = 41.4 and N? = 42.4 For ? = 25o , Nc = 25.1, Nq = 12.7 and N? = 9.7 . Assume ?sat = 18.5 kN/m3 , ? (above WT) = 17.5 kN/m3 , Factor of Safety = 3 If the water table occupies any of the positions (i) 1.25 m below Ground Level (ii) 1.25 m below the base level of the foundation, What will be the net safe bearing pressure?

Level 5 - Evaluate level Question A site is under investigation for the construction of a new Hospital. In the investigation it is found that top 3m of the soil is of Medium sand compact and dry. Next 4m is of black cotton soil. Then again for 2m the soil is of medium sand. Then rock strata starts. What type of foundation can be suggested for this site for the construction of a 4 storey hospital building?

Level 6 - Create level Question Design a shallow foundation to support column load 800kN, base of footing is expected at 3ft below the ground level, having a cohesion c = 30 kN/m2 and angle of shearing resistance ? = 35deg. The moist weight of soil above the water table is 17.25 kN/m2 . For ? = 35deg, Nc = 57.8, Nq = 41.4 and N? = 42.4

In the discussion forum shown below post all the advantages and limitations of :

a) Videos
Advantages:This is tool tool/application to teach students via visualization. Help student getting realistic view.
Limitations:Infrastructure is a big issue. All the topics cannot be covered via videos

b) Animations
Advantages:Can be a good tool/application to animate things that cannot be easily available. 
Limitations:All the topics cannot be covered via videos. Expertise is needed

c) Simulations

Course - Environmental Engineering

b.	a component to operate within a vacuum furnace at 2100 °C,
c.	a component of diesel engine which is subject to wear

Questions for Recall level to create level – Design of concrete structures
Here I have enclosed a set questions for 6 levels of Taxonomy which is used in Design of concrete structures. Please Review it, and provide me feedback. Thanks.
Level 1 - Recall Level Question Write the equation for the extreme fiber stresses in prestressed concrete beam sections.
Level 2 - Understand level Question Explain how the stresses induced in PSC beam due to application of loads.
Level 3 - Apply level Question A prestressed concrete beam 500mm x750mm in section has a span 8m aand is subjected to a uniformly distributed load of 17.50 kN/m including the self wt. of the beam .The prestressing tendons are located at the lower third pt. of the section and provide an effective stresses in concrete  for the mid span section. Solve by following  methods: stress concept method, strain concept method, load balancing concept. Take prestressing force 1000kN
Level 4 - Analyze level question A rectangular concrete beam 100 mm wide by 250 mm deep spanning over 8m is prestressed by a straight cable carrying an effective pretsressing force of 250kN, locate at an eccentricity of 40 mm. If the beam supports a live load of 1.2 kN/m,(i) calculate the resultant stresses at the central cross-section of the beam. Concrete weight 24 kN/m3. (ii) Find the magnitude of the prestressing force with an eccentricity of 40mm which can balance the stress due to dead and live loads at the bottom fibre of the section at the centre of the span. 
Level 5 - Evaluate level Question A post tensioned beam of rectangular section 125mm wide & 300mm deep. The beam is prestressed by a parabolic tendon. The eccentricity of the tendon is zero at each support & 55mm at the centre of the span. The area of the tendon is 215mm2 and the tendons are initially stressed to 1200 N/mm2 . The ultimate creep strain may be taken as 27x10-6 mm per N/mm2 of the stress in concrete. Find the loss of prestress due to creep of concrete. Take Es= 2x105 N/mm2
Level 6 - Create level Question Design PSC I section beam for the following span=18m, superimposed load = 30kN/m, cube strength of concrete at 28 days is 35kN/m2, safe stress in concrete at transfer= 0.5 fck, allowable tensile stress in concrete is 0.279(fck)1/2  , safe stress in steel in steel is 1200MPa, total loss of stress 20%, ultimate stress in steel 1200 MPa.

URL - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_Tracer

Packet Tracer is a cross-platform visual simulation program designed by Cisco Systems that allows users to create network topologies and imitate modern computer networks. 

The software allows users to simulate the configuration of Cisco routers and switches using a simulated command line interface. 

Packet Tracer makes use of a drag and drop user interface, allowing users to add and remove simulated network devices as they see fit.

Topic: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics

Unit: Basic understanding of Partial Molar Properties

Target Audience: Pre Final year UG Chemical Engineering Students

Learning objectives: (1) Students will be able to understand the basic concept of partial properties (2) Students will be able to derive the general equation of partial molar properties for calculating the contribution of each component in a solution (3) Students will be able to calculate solution properties from the knowledge of partial molar properties and vice –versa. 

Question set for Resource Creation Assignment: 

Recall: Apply basic concept of ideal and non-ideal solution for partial properties.

Understand: Can you make required amount of solution based on the given data of partial molar property of components?

Analysis: If the value of one of the partial property of component is changed, what will be the effect on partial property of other components? 

Evaluate: For a given condition of solution to be formed, one has to develop fundamental equation relating to solution properties and partial properties. 

Create: Identify the maximum amount of components to be required to mix to form the desired amount of solution. Derive and calculate solution properties from partial molar properties and vice –versa.

Topic : Convolution
Recall: State the formula for obtaining the convolution of two discrete time signals x[n] and h[n].

Understand : If we convolve the discrete time signals  x[n] = {1 , 2, 3, 4} for n= -1 to 2 and  h[n] = {1,1,3,2,1,4} for n= -2 to 3, for what values of n the output signal y[n] is nonzero?

Apply: Obtain the output of LTI system whose impulse response h[n] = u[n] for the input signal x[n] = u[n-1].

Analyze: Consider the discrete time system accumulator or summer. Weather this system is invertible? Justify your answer.

Evaluate:   Consider  cascade connection of LTI systems with impulse responses h1[n] and h2[n], where  h1[n] = u[n] – u[n-2]  and the overall impulse response is  { 3,2,1,6,4} for n= -1 to 3 compute the impulse response of h2[n].

Create:  Consider the system with impulse response h[n] = 2 ?[n-3] . Design the system which when connected in cascade with above system gives the output same as input.

Limitations:

**ANIMATIONS** 

Advantages:

1.	Very useful for the concepts or process which are difficult to explain with video.
2.	It can be made as per requirement of the teacher and learner.

Limitations:

1.	It requires certain technical skill to make animations.
2.	It requires time and tools to do.

**SIMULATIONS** 

Advantages:

1.	It is more interactive to the user,
2.	It provide certain room to think to change parameters and observe the effect

Limitations:

Topics

    Polynomials
    Error Analysis

Description

With your mouse, drag data points and their error bars, and watch the best-fit polynomial curve update instantly. You choose the type of fit: linear, quadratic, cubic, or quartic. The reduced chi-square statistic shows you when the fit is good. Or you can try to find the best fit by manually adjusting fit parameters.
Sample Learning Goals

    Explain how the range and uncertainty and number of data points affect correlation coefficient and chi squared
    Describe how correlation coefficient and chi squared can be used to indicate how well a curve describes the data relationship
    Apply understanding of Curve Fitting to designing experiments

Classroom A:
Advantages:
1.Gives the instructor the chance to expose students to unpublished or not readily available material.
2.Allows the instructor to precisely determine the aims, content, organization, pace and direction of a presentation.

Disadvantages:
1.Places students in a passive rather than an active role, which hinders learning.
2.Encourages one-way communication.

Classroom B:
Advantages:
1.Modern teaching methods create more interest among the students with the help of interesting animations and videos.

2. Research has shown that use of visual media for teaching helps the students to understand the subject better and also helps students to memorise the concept for longer time.
Disadvantages:
1.Barrier to student-teacher interactions.
2.Clarity can be lost & essential details overlooked while explaining a topic with a technological teaching aid.

We do invest significant time and resources in developing our teaching capability based on International best practice models. We do participate in a variety workshop, seminars and conferences and some of us have pursued specialist teaching qualifications. All of these activities were aimed at delivering on our Strategic Plan commitments as represented in goals. We try to make ourselves available for students. We have our knowledge accessible to students, we also takes care to produce an independent learner. To achieve these goals it is imperative that students actively engage with the curriculum and the teaching process and that they develop a motivation and discipline to learn in both group and individual settings. This strategy was developed to facilitate achievement of these goals. This strategy represents our approach to delivering the best possible learning experience for students that will promote independent learning and academic achievement. In implementing the strategy departments and lecturers will strive to ensure that students are exposed to modern, effective teaching models that engage students. Let us summarize the discussion as follows: OBJECTIVES: articulate the knowledge and skills we want students to acquire by the end of the course ASSESSMENTS: allow the instructor to check the degree to which the students are meeting the learning objectives

A human can distinguish differences in line length, shape orientation, and color (hue) readily without significant processing effort; these are referred to as "pre-attentive attributes." For example, it may require significant time and effort ("attentive processing") to identify the number of times the digit "5" appears in a series of numbers; but if that digit is different in size, orientation, or colour, instances of the digit can be noted quickly through pre-attentive processing. \nEffective graphics take advantage of pre-attentive processing and attributes and the relative strength of these attributes. For example, since humans can more easily process differences in line length than surface area, it may be more effective to use a bar chart (which takes advantage of line length to show comparison) rather than pie charts (which use surface area to show comparison).\n

Simulations: They are visually effective and interactive in nature. But they are time consuming.

The advantages are:

a) Videos
1. Real world examples result in better comprehension

b) Animations
1. Summarizes the trajectory or motion along all instants which give a clearer picture than videos

c) Simulations
1. Enables visualization of endless possibilities of the problem based on user setting of parameters.

The disadvantages are:

a) Videos
1. Do not summarize or analyze the problem shown in previous frames and only give information regarding the current frame

b) Animations
1. Do not describe all possible situations that could occur and analyzes one particular situation that is predefined.

c) Simulations
1. Artificial environment though interactive offer no clue of a real-world situation like videos do.

Questions for Recall level to create level – Design of Prestressed Concrete Beam
Here I have enclosed a set questions for 6 levels of Taxonomy which is used in Design of Prestressed Concrete Beam. Please Review it, and provide me feedback. Thanks.
Level 1 - Recall Level Question Write the equation for the extreme fiber stresses in prestressed concrete beam sections.
Level 2 - Understand level Question Explain how the stresses induced in PSC beam due to application of loads.
Level 3 - Apply level Question A prestressed concrete beam 500mm x750mm in section has a span 7m aand is subjected to a uniformly distributed load of 16 kN/m including the self wt. of the beam .The prestressing tendons are located at the lower third pt. of the section and provide an effective stresses in concrete  for the mid span section. Solve by following  methods: stress concept method, strain concept method, load balancing concept. Take prestressing force 1100kN
Level 4 - Analyze level question A rectangular concrete beam 100 mm wide by 250 mm deep spanning over 7.5m is prestressed by a straight cable carrying an effective pretsressing force of 300kN, locate at an eccentricity of 40 mm. If the beam supports a live load of 1.2 kN/m,(i) calculate the resultant stresses at the central cross-section of the beam. Concrete weight 24 kN/m3. (ii) Find the magnitude of the prestressing force with an eccentricity of 40mm which can balance the stress due to dead and live loads at the bottom fibre of the section at the centre of the span. 
Level 5 - Evaluate level Question A post tensioned beam of rectangular section 125mm wide & 300mm deep. The beam is prestressed by a parabolic tendon. The eccentricity of the tendon is zero at each support & 50mm at the centre of the span. The area of the tendon is 215mm2 and the tendons are initially stressed to 1250 N/mm2 . The ultimate creep strain may be taken as 27x10-6 mm per N/mm2 of the stress in concrete. Find the loss of prestress due to creep of concrete. Take Es= 2x105 N/mm2
Level 6 - Create level Question Design PSC I section beam for the following span=18m, superimposed load = 32kN/m, cube strength of concrete at 28 days is 35kN/m2, safe stress in concrete at transfer= 0.5 fck, allowable tensile stress in concrete is 0.279(fck)1/2  , safe stress in steel in steel is 1200MPa, total loss of stress 20%, ultimate stress in steel 1200 MPa.

**Summarizing Tool :**

 - 1 . URL -  http://www.get2gist.com
 - Get2Gist is an online text analytics tool that generates automatic summary of unstructured data pasted as text, 
uploaded via Word/PDF document, or through a link from a supported website.
The tool simultaneously generates interactive word cloud to facilitate searching of keywords within the content,
explore relationship between top keywords as well as generate summary of passages that contain the selected keyword.
- 2 . URL  - http://smmry.com
SMMRY has a minimalist style but there are lots of features to discover. 
Using this tool you set the number of sentence you want the text summarized in. 
It offers the option of pasting in text, uploading a file (only PDFs are permitted), or inputting 
the URL of the webpage you want summarized.

**Classifying Tools**

 - 1 . URL - https://photos.google.com/

 - All your photos are backed up safely, organized and labeled automatically, so you can find them fast,and share them how you like.

 - 2 . URL  - https://delicious.com/

 - Tool allows to discover, share, and organize the links online

Course : Industrial Engineering
Topic : Productivity

Questions bases on revised Bloom's Taxonomy:

1) Recall: Define productivity.

2) Understand: Give an example of productivity improvement in machine shop.

3) Apply: How to improve the productivity for a manufacturing set-up by reducing the set-up time?

4) Analyze: Analyze the cycle time for manufacturing of a shaft & suggest the elements for cycle time reduction.

5) Evaluate: Suggest an alternate method for improving productivity of shaft and evaluate the effectiveness of proposed method.

6) Create: Propose a new method for manufacturing of shaft which reduces set-up time and cycle time hence improves the productivity.

**Topic:** Selection Sort

**Learning objective:** Student should be able to sort the given data using selection sort.

**url of the visualization:** https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ns4TPTC8whw&feature=youtu.be

**Active learning strategy:**  After three numbers are sorted, I will pause the video, and ask the students to write down the steps for the next number to sort. Then I will saw the video for the next number, again will pause the video, and tell the students to check the work they have done, if incorrect, I will tell them to write the correct steps. Two to three students will share what were the wrong steps they have done. Again I will continue the video for next two numbers. And I will repeat the above steps for the next number.
